In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful

Presentation

This is the eighth collection of "Nawadir al-Makhtutat" (Rare Manuscripts), and it includes the book of 'Arram ibn al-Asbagh al-Sulami on (The Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them). It also includes the (General Indices) for the second volume of Rare Manuscripts, according to the system followed in the first volume.

I had promised to publish this book in the first collection of "Nawadir al-Makhtutat," but the opportunity to publish it did not arise at that time. Circumstances concurred that led me to publish it separately outside the scope of Rare Manuscripts. Then I saw fit to fulfill the promise I made, so I am republishing it within the scope of the Anecdotes (Nawadir) in an edition that is more complete and illuminating than that first edition.

This second edition is distinguished by the addition of several corrections and comments that came to us after the performance of the first edition, as well as some corrections and comments by the Professor Sheikh Hamad al-Jasir. Among its distinguishing features is the holding of an investigative comparison between my first and second editions of the book and the edition of the friend and erudite scholar Abd al-Aziz al-Maymani al-Rajkuti, Professor at Aligarh University in India [India]. Also, the addition of the page numbers of the original manuscript.

The system of Nawadir al-Makhtutat required that I cancel the indices specific to this treatise to merge them into the General Index for this second volume of the Anecdotes, which is appended to this collection. I did not retain any of those specific indices except for the index of Plants and Animals, because they have no counterpart in the General Indices.

Introduction to the Investigation for the First Edition (1)

Tihamah: "Tihamah" is a word whose indication varies severely. It extends in length from Aden [Yemen] to the borders of Al-Sham [Levant] running parallel to the coast of the sea, and it sometimes shrinks from the north or from the south. The ancient geographers differ on this. Perhaps the truest evidence for this is what 'Arram mentioned at the beginning of this book of his, that the first of the mountains of Tihamah is "Radwa", which is a day's journey from Yanbu [Saudi Arabia]. It seems that this expansion and contraction occurred in various eras as a result of the political or tribal authority that prevailed in that region or retreated from it.

However, the language aids us completely in this issue, as the derivation of Tihamah is from "Al-Taham", which is the changing of the wind, its stagnation, and the intensity of the heat. Thus, the coastal extension from the south of Yemen [Yemen] to the borders of Al-Sham [Levant] is what this naming applies to.

Anyone referring to the statements of ancient scholars will understand that the division of the Arabian Peninsula is subject to some extent to the Hejaz [Hejaz], which is the extended mountain range that separates two contrasting geographical sections of the Peninsula: one is elevated, which is Najd [Najd], and the other is lower than it and sunken, which is the Ghor (depression) of Tihamah. The Sarat of this mountain, meaning its heights, is what is called Al-Sarat, extending from the furthest Yemen to the nearest Sham. By geographical nature, Tihamah is the narrow depression that runs parallel to the Sea of Qulzum [Red Sea],

striking from the Arab side of the Sinai Peninsula [Egypt] to the furthest south of the lands of Yemen [Yemen]. Its width varies greatly; between Al-Tur and Suez [Egypt], it is a narrow part of the coast (1). The widest place in Tihamah is the coast of Jeddah [Saudi Arabia]. There is Tihamah of Yemen, and Tihamah of Hejaz.

Tihamah of Yemen was in some eras a province existing on its own, especially during the Persian conquest of Yemen at the end of the sixth century AD. Then, the Banu Ziyad governed this Tihamah later, and its capital was "Zabid" [Yemen], then it became a province subject to the Imams of Sanaa [Yemen]. There is another Tihamah outside the Arabian Peninsula, which is on the western shore of the sea, and it is (Tihamah of Abyssinia), mentioned by Ibn Khordadbeh (2), and he means by that what is known today as the coast of "Eritrea" [Eritrea].

As for the Tihamah that 'Arram means in this book of his, it is (Tihamah of Hejaz) without doubt. He makes its first northern mountains "Radwa", which is a day from Yanbu [Saudi Arabia] and seven stages from Medina [Saudi Arabia], and its southern limit is Taif [Saudi Arabia] and its villages.

Although the appearance of this book is that it is specific to the mountains of Tihamah and its inhabitants and what relates to it, the reality is that it includes discussion of Tihamah and Hejaz. We find that what pertains to Tihamah ends when it approaches three-fifths of the book, i.e., on page 49. Then we find a chapter devoted to the border of Hejaz, dealing with many of the towns, villages, mountains, and Hejazi locations adjacent to Medina [Saudi Arabia]. Although their mention came as a consequence of mentioning Tihamah due to their contiguity and proximity to it, they obtained an ample share of 'Arram's attention and occupied an authentic place in the book.

When you reach the conclusion of the book, you find this text: "The book of the names of the mountains of Mecca and Medina and what connects to them is completed." This text might suggest that they are two books, one for Tihamah and the other for Mecca and Medina. The matter is only as I mentioned regarding 'Arram's digression, and that the word "Kitab" (book) only means what he wrote...

in this area. The ancients did not mention for 'Arram any book except this one, "Book of the Names of the Mountains of Tihamah", and from it, narrators and authors quote.

Attribution of this book:
This book is attributed to "Abu al-Ash'ath al-Kindi (1)", who is Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn Abd al-Malik, and he is the one who narrated the book directly from "'Arram". I did not find a biography for Abu al-Ash'ath, but it is likely that he is from the men of the third century, as his Sheikh "Ibn Abi Sa'd" died in the year 274 [Note: The text says 174 here but footnote 3 on page 395 corrects Ibn Abi Sa'd's death to 274, likely a typo in this specific line or referring to birth? Context suggests 3rd century scholar]. It is strange that Yaqut did not attribute the book to 'Arram in his introduction, but attributed it to him in different places within the body of the book.

This book is also attributed to "Al-Sakuni". Al-Bakri said: "And all that he cited in this book from Al-Sakuni is from the book of Abu Ubayd Allah ibn Bishr al-Sakuni (2) on the mountains of Tihamah and its localities; he carries all of that from Abu al-Ash'ath Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn Abd al-Malik al-Kindi, from 'Arram ibn al-Asbagh al-Sulami the Bedouin."

I referred to the texts that Al-Bakri attributed in his dictionary to Al-Sakuni and found many of them exceeding our book here, which indicates that "Al-Sakuni" made the book his basis in narration but added to it many comments and additions, as was the custom of many ancient narrators of books.

Examples of this include what appeared on page 659 of Al-Bakri's dictionary: "Al-Sakuni said with his chain of narration from Musa ibn Ishaq ibn 'Umarah who said: We passed by Al-Bughaybighah with Muhammad ibn Abd Allah ibn Hasan and it was inhabited. He said: Do you marvel at it? By Allah, you will die until not a green thing remains in it, then you will live, then you will die. And Al-Sakuni said in mentioning the waters of Damrah: Al-Bughaybighah, Ghayqah, and the tails of Al-Safra were...

1. Introduction to Mu'jam al-Buldan by Yaqut, p. 8.
2. This Al-Sakuni is also a Kindi like Abu al-Ash'ath, for Al-Sakun, with a Fatha on the Seen, is a branch of Kinda.

waters for Banu Ghifar of Damrah. Al-Sakuni said: Al-Abbas ibn al-Hasan used to frequently describe Yanbu [Saudi Arabia] to Al-Rashid, so he said to him one day: Bring its description closer to me. So he said: O Valley of the Palace, what an excellent Palace and Valley... a home for a settler if you wish, or a nomad. You find its small boats anchored at the basin... and the lizard, the fish, the sailor, and the saffron/wine." This is a clear text that it is not from 'Arram's book, and not from what Al-Sakuni narrated from 'Arram.

And on page 811: "Al-Sakuni narrated from his men from Tariq ibn Abd al-Rahman, who said to Sa'id ibn al-Musayyib: We passed by the Mosque of the Tree and prayed in it. He said: And from where is that known? He said: I heard people saying it..." etc. This is a comment on "Al-Hudaybiyyah" and its mosque, which is the Mosque of the Tree, and this is not from 'Arram's book at all.

And this is a third text not from 'Arram's book nor from his method in his book. Al-Sakuni (1) said: If you want to collect the sadaqah (charity tax) of the Bedouins up to Al-'Ajz - meaning the rear of Hawazin - you depart from Medina [Saudi Arabia] and descend at Dhu al-Ghussa, which belongs to the Sultan, and collect from Banu 'Uwal of Banu Tha'labah ibn Sa'd. Then you descend at Al-Abraq, Abraq al-Hima, which belongs to Banu Abi Talib. Then you descend at Al-Rabadhah, then 'Urayj, which belongs to Haram ibn 'Adi ibn Jusham ibn Mu'awiyah. Then you descend at Al-Ma'izah - and it is said Al-Ma'iziyah - which belongs to Banu Amir, of Banu al-Baka'. Then you descend at Batn Turabah and collect from Hilal ibn Amir and Al-Dabab. Then you descend at Tarim which belongs to Banu Jusham. Then you descend at Al-Sayy and collect from Banu Hilal. Then Nasifah, which belongs to Banu Zaman ibn 'Adi ibn Jusham. Then Al-Shisah, which belongs to Banu Zaman also. Then you graze [or pass Tur'a], which belongs to Banu Jada'ah. Then you come to Buwanah.

This is damning evidence that Al-Sakuni's book on the mountains of Tihamah is a free narration of 'Arram's book that relied on many comments and digressive additions, and Al-Bakri was loose in his expression in the statement I quoted from him.

Regardless, this copy of ours has a noble chain of transmission (Isnad), narrated by Al-Sirafi, who is said to have written a book on the Arabian Peninsula, from Abu Muhammad al-Sukkari, from Abu Sa'd, from Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn Abd al-Malik known as Abu al-Ash'ath al-Kindi, from 'Arram.

'Arram ibn al-Asbagh al-Sulami:
We have not found a biography for 'Arram, except what Ibn al-Nadim (1) mentioned casually when listing the names of the Bedouins who entered the metropolis. He mentioned him as a peer of Abu al-Haytham the Bedouin, Abu al-Mujib al-Rab'i, and Abu al-Jarrah al-'Uqayli. He mentioned him by his full name, "'Arram ibn al-Asbagh al-Sulami". It seems he was one of the Bedouins of Banu Sulaym who used to roam the lands and learn their paths, thereby gaining truthful expertise. The derivation of "'Arram" is from 'Aramah, meaning intensity, strength, and fierceness. It is said: The child was 'arim ('aramna) and became fierce ('aruma) against us, meaning he became ill-natured, or it is said he became merry and insolent, or it is said he became corrupt. "Al-Asbagh" is his father's name, taken from Al-Asbagh, which is a horse whose forelock has turned completely white, or a bird whose tail has turned white.

'Arram the Grammarian:
As for the 'Arram mentioned by Ibn al-Nadim in Al-Fihrist (1), and Al-Qifti (2) in Inbah al-Ruwat, he is a nickname for one of the grammarians. 'Arram is not the name of that grammarian but a nickname for him; his name was Abu al-Fadl al-Abbas ibn Muhammad, or Al-Mufaddal ibn Abbas ibn Muhammad. This grammarian was, as they mentioned, impudent, foolish, and light-witted, and he is undoubtedly different from 'Arram ibn al-Asbagh, whose book this is considered one of the most important geographical documents, and indeed one of the authentic mother references.

The Original Copy:
The original of this copy is unique in the libraries of the world, and it is preserved in the Sa'idiyya Library in Hyderabad [India] in a collection numbered (365 Hadith), and its date goes back to the year 876. The copy is in six folios, meaning twelve pages, with 25 lines on each page. The page size is 18 ... 20. It is difficult to read, written in an obscure, poor Naskh script with much neglect of dots, and it is full of distortion (tahrif) and misspelling (tashif). I have overcome the...

I also consulted language dictionaries and other books in all the arts required for investigation, sparing no effort to make this book appear as close as possible to soundness.

Investigation of this book:
I knew nothing about the existence of this book except what frequently caught my eye when reviewing geographical dictionaries mentioning ('Arram ibn al-Asbagh al-Sulami), until the day I met the generous friend (Sheikh Sulayman al-Sani'). I had begun a scientific work aiming to publish rare small manuscripts, from which I produced two collections containing nine rare books under the name "Nawadir al-Makhtutat". The brother informed me that he had a manuscript worthy of publication, which is this book of 'Arram, and promised to send it to me from Hejaz [Saudi Arabia] so I could investigate and publish it. He fulfilled what he promised and sent the copy to me. I found it to be a manuscript from the year 1368, copied from a version transcribed by Sheikh Ibrahim Hamdi, the director of the Sheikh al-Islam Arif Hikmat Library in Medina [Saudi Arabia], from the Indian copy. This copy of Brother Sheikh Sulayman had been cared for by him through revision and verification of some of its places. Then the venerable Sheikh (Sayyid Muhammad Nasif) kindly wrote to me, supporting Sheikh Sulayman's wish with his own noble wish, and sent me another copy transcribed by Sheikh Abd al-Rahman ibn Yahya al-Yamani from the Indian original with precision, mastery, and conformity to the original.

But all that did not satisfy my scientific conscience, since the original of the book exists and it is possible to obtain it. So I seized the opportunity of the trip of the dutiful brother (Professor Rashad Abd al-Muttalib) to India [India] in a mission for the Arab League to bring photocopies of its precious manuscripts. I recommended him to bring with him a copy of 'Arram's book. He had the great credit of being able to procure it, so it was the original I relied upon in publishing this book. Thanks are due to the brother (Sheikh Sulayman al-Sani') for the favor he extended by introducing me to this...

Critique of the First Edition

That is what I wrote in the preface of my first edition of 'Arram's book. I was greatly pleased that about three months after the appearance of this edition, a scientific critique of it appeared by the pen of the scholar brother Sheikh Hamad al-Jasir, member of the Arab Scientific Academy in Damascus [Syria], in the Academy's Journal Vol. 28: Issue 3, pp. 396-402 dated Shawwal 1372, and Issue 4, pp. 592-599 dated Muharram 1373.

I am one of those who admire criticism greatly and see it as a completion of fulfilling the scientific trust carried by all scholars, not borne by one of them alone. I also see that whoever conceals the trust is sinful against it and against science. So it was natural for me to receive that criticism with joy, and it was also natural for me to turn a blind eye to what the critic sometimes rushes into of language that resembles the impulses of a victor in the heat of battle, for they are impulses from which few have protected their human selves.

I had previously called for criticism among literati to follow a high path of modes of expression, and to be free from personal factors. I wrote long ago, among what I wrote in Al-Thaqafa Magazine, Issue 647, May 1951: "Literary criticism is no longer, as it was yesterday, defamation and libel against the criticized. Rather, it is time that we adopt seriousness regarding what touches the standings of literati and their scientific dignity, for stumbling is a matter that happens to all literati; no one doubts this except the deluded, the insane, or the weak-souled. The matter of criticism is nothing more than assistance and discussion of opinion, or participation in guiding to the truth. Criticism is forever a servant of science, and is not a trivial type of satire arts; rather, it is a high art approached by the literatus with a tolerant character and noble discourse."

In this spirit, which I cherish and whose inspiration I truly believe in, I publish the beginning of Professor Al-Jasir's word, a generous word that I had hoped would be free from some lapses that...

I return here to say: The copy that reached us of 'Arram's book is deeply rooted in misspelling and distortion, difficult to read, such that it puts the investigator in a struggle with every one of its words, and sometimes between every letter of the letters of its words. Whatever effort and endeavor an investigator exerts, he is not able to edit it completely. Therefore, I also declare my joy with what this treatise obtained of verifications, corrections, and comments by the generous critic Professor, totaling over twenty. The reader will see the effect of what I found correct from these criticisms and comments in their places, Allah willing.

Professor Al-Jasir thought of us that we had seen Professor Al-Maymani's edition when investigating the first edition, and that we hid that from the readers!! This is a naive accusation for which we hope for him a wide forgiveness from Allah. For I did not see this copy for the first time until the afternoon of Thursday, 11 Shawwal 1374, in the house of his friend and our friend Professor Rashad Abd al-Muttalib.

Names of the Mountains of Tihamah
Authored by: 'Arram ibn al-Asbagh al-Sulami
Investigated by: Abd al-Salam Harun, Assistant Professor at Cairo University [Egypt]

The publishing of this treatise has a story we summarize by saying that Sheikh Ibrahim al-Kharbutli, Director of the (Sheikh al-Islam) Library in Medina [Saudi Arabia] (died 1371), visited India [India] in the year 1357. He saw the erudite investigator Sheikh Abd al-Aziz al-Maymani, member of the Arab Scientific Academy, copying it. He helped him in comparing what he copied against the original, and he copied a version himself which he brought to Hejaz. When he passed through Jeddah [Saudi Arabia], he stayed as a guest of the noble, gracious Sayyid Muhammad Husayn Nasif and showed him this copy. Sheikh Nasif copied it and showed it to many of those concerned with knowledge among scholars and others. Among those who copied it from Sheikh Nasif's copy was Sheikh Sulayman al-Sani'. He exerted a commendable effort in correcting it by comparing what was in it against Mu'jam al-Buldan, Mu'jam Ma Asta'jam, and other books, since Sheikh Al-Kharbutli's copy had much distortion and error, in addition to what was in the original of that.

When he visited Egypt [Egypt], he informed Professor Abd al-Salam Muhammad Harun about the matter of this treatise so he could publish it in a collection of rare treatises (1), and he sent him a copy after returning from Egypt. However, he did not publish it, but said in the introduction to the second collection of (Nawadir al-Makhtutat) p. 116: "I had intended to publish in this collection the book of 'Arram ibn al-Asbagh al-Sulami on the Names of the Mountains of Tihamah... but I learned that the Erudite Abd al-Aziz al-Maymani al-Rajkuti had published this book, so I preferred to postpone doing so until I see his copy."

As for Sheikh Al-Maymani, he published the treatise - as Professor Abd al-Salam mentioned - in the magazine of the Oriental College published in the city of Lahore in Pakistan [Pakistan]: (Oriental

College Magazine), after writing an introduction for it describing the original, speaking about the author of the treatise, and referring to something of the news of the Sa'idiyya Library where it was found.

Sheikh Muhammad Nasif wanted to publish this treatise - because he had not seen what Sheikh Al-Maymani published - so he sent it to the (Arab Scientific Academy). It was returned to him and he was told: So-and-so - the writer of this article - should undertake correcting it. So he sent it to me, but I saw that investigating it usefully required obtaining a photostatic copy (photograph) of the original. I expressed to Sheikh Nasif the unsuitability of his copy for publication before comparing it against the original with precise comparison. So he sent it to Sheikh Abd al-Rahman al-Mu'allimi al-Yamani - who was then in India [India] among those in charge of publishing books printed by the Osmania Encyclopedia in (Hyderabad) - so he compared it against the original precisely, and copied another copy from the original which he sent to Sheikh Nasif. By comparing that copy, it appeared that Sheikh Al-Kharbutli's copy had much distortion and error.

Then Sheikh Muhammad Nasif saw fit to publish the treatise, and that Professor Abd al-Salam Harun should undertake publishing it. The Cultural Department of the Arab League had sent Sayyid Muhammad Rashad Abd al-Muttalib to India [India] to photograph some rare Arabic manuscripts. Among what he photographed was the original of this treatise. I was keen when I was in Cairo [Egypt] to see the copy photographed by the Cultural Department, but I was unable to do so despite the connection between me and Sayyid Muhammad Rashad - which I consider strong - and he had kindly lent me a copy of the copies printed by Professor Al-Maymani. I contacted the venerable Professor Sheikh Muhibb al-Din al-Khatib and spoke with him on the subject of publishing it, but he said: The matter requires the existence of a copy of the original.

Perhaps Allah intended good for this treatise - by reviving and investigating it by an investigating scholar of expertise, knowledge, and long endurance, who is Professor Abd al-Salam Harun. We have no blame to direct at our brothers in Egypt [Egypt] whose private circumstances might prevent us from seeing what we wish to see of the books we have a right to see -

especially the manuscripts of the Cultural Department - yes, we have no right to blame them, for perhaps they have an excuse we are ignorant of. However, we know - as they know - that mutual support, assistance, and cooperation in the path of knowledge are matters that must be prioritized over every consideration.

As for our word about Professor Abd al-Salam - in his investigation of this treatise - it contains some disagreement with him regarding the investigation, a disagreement I did not wish for, as disagreement is evil in all its aspects, but the duty of science mandates it. I have said in words published in (Al-Risalah, the Journal of the Scientific Academy, Al-Fath Magazine, and Al-Hajj Magazine) that some of our university brothers like Professor Mustafa... and Professor Dr. Zaki... undertook the investigation or translation of some works in a manner not befitting their high scientific standing. I feared that what was said about some famous scholars satisfying themselves with putting their names on the work intended for investigation, while entrusting the matter to some of their brothers who do not reach their standing - I feared this might be true.

As for Professor Abd al-Salam, I absolve him of this stigma, because I have witnessed from the effects of his work in investigating some ancient works what I have not witnessed from many who concern themselves with that. I wished to find in this treatise what I found in other books he investigated, or more than what I found. However - although I saw in it what pleases, benefits, and entertains - I saw all this as little compared to what I expected from the Professor. To indicate my saying, it behooves me to mention some of what I saw in need of more care.

Professor Abd al-Salam did not indicate that the Erudite Al-Maymani published this treatise (1), and scientific honesty and acknowledging every right holder's right mandate not concealing the effort of this investigator (2)

I would not be exaggerating if I say that his effort in investigating this treatise is not less than the effort of Professor Abd al-Salam, if not surpassing it. For example, Al-Maymani clarified 'Arram's condition and era, mentioning that he was from the people of the second and early third century (1) and that he was among those who entered Khorasan with Abd Allah ibn Tahir in the year 217. These are among the matters that Professor Harun missed, and they are indispensable matters, as knowing the author is the most important thing a book investigator cares for.

It might be said that the Professor is ignorant of the fact that Al-Maymani undertook the investigation of this treatise. But this is refuted by several things:

This matter - the publisher ignoring the predecessor's effort in investigating what he publishes - is something criticized in Professor Al-Saqqa and some university scholars. We wished for Professor Abd al-Salam Harun to be above it (1).

Professor Abd al-Salam said in the introduction to the treatise: "The original of this copy is unique in the libraries of the world, and it is a manuscript in the Sa'idiyya Library in Hyderabad [India] in a collection numbered 355 Hadith, and its date goes back to the year 876. The copy is in six folios (meaning twelve pages)."

Thus said the Professor, but we find Professor Al-Maymani, when describing the treatise, saying: "There exists in the Sa'idiyya Treasury in Hyderabad a collection containing 27 treatises on Hadiths and Men (Rijal). The first is 'Khalq Af'al al-Ibad' by Al-Bukhari. The completion of its writing corresponded to 18 Jumada al-Ula year 786. It is established on the margin of the epilogue: Comparison reached against the original transmitted from in sessions, the last of which was on the night dawning into Thursday of Dhu al-Hijjah the Sacred, year 787, its scribe Muhammad ibn Ali. But despite this empty claim, it is a sign in misspelling and distortion. The number of 'Arram's book in it is 16, between pages 151 - 159, meaning it fell in nine pages only."

This is what Professor Al-Maymani said, and it contradicts Professor Abd al-Salam's description regarding the date of copying and the number of pages. Which of them is correct in speech? It appears Al-Maymani is the correct one (2), and that Professor Abd al-Salam quoted the copying date from Sulayman al-Sani's copy, who copied it from a copy whose original is Al-Kharbutli's copy, in which the date appeared as Professor Harun mentioned. However, when Sheikh Nasif sent it to India to be compared against the original, Professor Abd al-Rahman al-Yamani corrected this place, as appeared in Professor Al-Maymani's copy. Added to that is that the sample the Professor reproduced photographically in his copy has nothing of the copying date, although it is the end of the treatise. It appears that those who photographed it photographed it alone while it was devoid of the date, so Professor Abd al-Salam relied on what was in Professor Al-Sani's copy, which is a mistake.

After Professor Ahmad [Hamad] al-Jasir presented these criticisms in two articles in the Academy's magazine, he said at the conclusion of his speech:

2. That might be regarding the date of copying, for my photocopy is devoid of it, and I relied on what reached me from Sheikh Sulayman al-Sani's copy. In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. My Lord, facilitate with good. Amen.

Abu Sa'id al-Hasan ibn Abd Allah al-Sirafi (1) said: Abu Muhammad Ubayd Allah ibn Abd al-Rahman al-Sukkari (2) informed us, reading to him. He said: Abd Allah ibn Amr ibn Abd al-Rahman al-Warraq, known as Ibn Abi Sa'd (3), told us. He said: Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn Abd al-Malik Abu al-Ash'ath told us. He said: 'Arram ibn al-Asbagh al-Sulami dictated to me, saying:
foot_note:
1. He is Al-Hasan ibn Abd Allah ibn al-Marzuban Abu Sa'id, the Judge Al-Sirafi, the Grammarian. His origin is from Siraf [Iran]. He lived on the East Side in Baghdad [Iraq] and held the judiciary there. His father was a Magian who converted to Islam, named Bahzadh, so he named him Abu Sa'id Abd Allah. He was one of the most knowledgeable people in the grammar of the Basrans, and followed the doctrine of the people of Iraq in jurisprudence. He read the Quran under Abu Bakr ibn Mujahid, and language under Abu Bakr ibn Durayd, and studied grammar under both. He read grammar under Abu Bakr ibn al-Sarraj and Abu Bakr al-Mubraman; one of them read readings to him and the other studied arithmetic under him. He was an ascetic who only ate from the earning of his hand and did not leave his house to the council of judgment and teaching every day until he copied ten pages for which he took a wage of ten dirhams. He has a commentary on Sibawayh's Book, the Book of News of Grammarians, the Book of Persuasion in Grammar, and the Book of the Arabian Peninsula. He was born before 290 and died in the year 368. Tarikh Baghdad (7: 341-342), Bughyat al-Wu'at 221, Mu'jam al-Udaba (8: 145-232), Al-Buldan (5: 193), Nuzhat al-Alba 379.
2. He is Ubayd Allah ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn Isa, Abu Muhammad al-Sukkari. He heard Zakariya ibn Yahya al-Manqari the companion of Al-Asma'i, Muhammad ibn al-Jarud al-Warraq, Ibrahim ibn al-Walid al-Jashshash, (Abd Allah ibn Abi Sa'd al-Warraq), and Abd Allah ibn Muslim ibn Qutaybah. Al-Ja'abi, Abu Umar ibn Haywayh, Ahmad ibn Ibrahim ibn Shadhan, and Abu al-Hasan al-Daraqutni narrated from him. He was a majestic trustworthy person. Died year 323. Tarikh Baghdad 5499. In the original: "Ubayd Allah ibn Abd Allah", a distortion.
3. In the original: "Abu Sa'id", distorted. He is Abd Allah ibn Amr ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Bishr ibn Hilal, Abu Muhammad al-Ansari al-Warraq, known as Ibn Abi Sa'd. Originally from Balkh [Afghanistan], he lived in Baghdad [Iraq] and narrated there from Al-Husayn ibn Muhammad al-Marwazi, Affan ibn Muslim, Sulayman ibn Harb, Hawdhah ibn Khalifah, Sulayman ibn Dawud al-Hashimi, and others. Ibn Abi al-Dunya, Abd Allah ibn Muhammad al-Baghawi, (Ubayd Allah ibn Abd al-Rahman al-Sukkari), Al-Husayn ibn al-Qasim al-Kawkabi, Al-Husayn ibn Isma'il al-Mahamili, and others narrated from him. He was trustworthy, a man of news, literature, and anecdotes. Born year 197 and died year 274. Tarikh Baghdad 5144.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text:
Names of the mountains of Tihamah and their inhabitants, and what villages are in them, and what trees grow on them, and what waters are in them.

The first of them is (Radwa) [Mount Radwa, Saudi Arabia], a day from Yanbu [Saudi Arabia], and seven stages from Medina [Saudi Arabia] to the right of the Medina road, and to its left is the road of Al-Barira (1) for one ascending to Mecca [Saudi Arabia], and it is two nights from the sea. Opposite it is ('Azwar (3)) [Mount Azwar, Saudi Arabia]. Between it and Radwa is the road of Al-Ma'raqah (4) which the Arabs use as a shortcut to Al-Sham [Levant], to Mecca, and to Medina. Between the two mountains is the extent of a horse run. They are two lofty, impregnable mountains that no one aspires to climb. Their vegetation is Shawhat (Yew?), Qaraz (Acacia), and Ranf (6), which is a tree resembling the Dahya'. The Dahya' is a tree resembling the jujube; camels and sheep eat it, and it has no fruit. The Dahya' has a fruit resembling the gallnut which is not eaten and has no taste or scent.
foot_note:
1. Al-Bakri 655: "Al-Barr", a distortion.
2. In Al-Maymani's copy: "bi-hidha'ihi" (opposite him), distorted from what is in the original.
3. With a Fatha on the first letter and Sukun on the Zay. The origin of the meaning of 'Azwar is bad-tempered. Umar ibn Abi Rabi'ah says about it:
She signaled that the tribe's departure time has come ... but your appointment is 'Azwar.
And Kuthayyir says:
She kept pace with the pilgrims from Batn Nakhlah ... and from 'Azwar and Al-Khabt, Khabt Tufayl.
4. Yaqut vocalized it with a Damma on the Meem, Sukun on the Ayn, and Kasra on the Ra. Then he said: It was narrated with Shadda on the Ra and Takhfif (lightening), which is the [correct] aspect, as if it is the road taking towards Iraq. Al-Bakri vocalized it with Fatha on the Meem and Ra. This road was taken by other than Quraysh when the Battle of Badr occurred.
5. Shortening the road: taking the nearest one.
6. With Sukun on the Nun. Abu Hanifa said: "Of the mountain trees, its leaves fold to its branches when night comes, and spread out by day."

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them

text:
And in both mountains are waters of Awshal - and the Washal is water that exits from its peak; no one approaches it (1) nor is its source known. None of those Awshal exceeds the shiqqah (distance/cleft) (2). He recited about the Ranf (3) describing a mountain:
Its playing grounds are Ranf, so the casting of its Sayyal ... are channels of Awshal whose flowing water crawls (4).
Their peaks and precincts (5) are inhabited by Nahd and Juhaynah, specifically the Wabar (Bedouins) excluding the Madar (settled people), and they have apparent wealth there. The two mountains pour into the valley of (Ghayqah), and Ghayqah pours (6) into the sea, and it has Masak (7), which are places (8) that hold water, singular Masak.

From the right of Radwa for one descending from Medina to the sea, at a night's distance from Radwa (9) is (Yanbu) [Saudi Arabia]. It has a pulpit (Minbar) and is a large, thriving village. Its inhabitants are the Ansar, Juhaynah,
foot_note:
1. La Yaturuha: Does not hover around it nor approach it. In Al-Maymani's copy: "min shawahiqihi" (from its peaks), distorted from what is in the original.
2. Al-Bakri: "With Kasra on its first letter and Shadda on its second." And he has 327: "As for Al-Bathnah, with Sukun on its second and Fatha on the Nun, on the weight of Fa'lah, it is land towards Suwayqah in Medina. Abd Allah ibn Hasan ibn Ali ibn Abi Talib worked it with the money of his wife Hind bint Abi Ubaydah ibn Abd Allah ibn Zam'ah and made its springs flow. It is Al-Bathnat. Before marrying her, he was destitute (miqlat). When Al-Bathnat was developed, he said to her: Whatever you step over of Al-Bathnah is yours. So she walked the length of Al-Khayf across three rows of palms. It is the right of her son Musa from him, who is called Al-Shiqqah."
3. In the original: "anshadani al-ramth" (he recited to me al-ramth). Al-Maymani made it in his copy: "wa anshada fi al-ramth" (and he recited about al-ramth). Both are distortions. Ranf was mentioned previously on p. 396.
4. Al-Sayyal like Sahab: A tree with white thorns, a type of 'Idah. Al-Madafi': Channels/Streams, singular Madfa' with Fatha on Meem. In the original: "yudafi'u".
5. Al-Dhara with Fatha: Shelter and shade. Al-Ahwaz: Areas/Sides, plural of Hawzah. Similarly Hadbah and Ahdab, Dhutah and Adhwat. In the original: "ajwaruhuma". See Al-Hamdani 117, 120.
6. Written thus in the original to be read with Ta and Ya together.
7. In the original: "masak", distorted.
8. In the original: "wa huwa mawdi'" (and it is a place).
9. Yaqut added from 'Arram: "from Medina at seven stages, and it belongs to Banu Hasan ibn Ali."

text:
and Layth also. It has abundant sweet springs. Its valley (Yalil) pours into Ghayqah. (And Al-Safra (1)) [Saudi Arabia] is a village with many palms and farms, and its water consists entirely of springs. It is above Yanbu towards Medina. Its water flows to Yanbu. It belongs to Juhaynah, the Ansar, Banu Fihr, and Nahd. Radwa is in the direction of the sunset from it. Around it are Qinan - singular Qunnah (peaks) - and small Da'adi' (hills) - singular Da'da'. Qinan and Da'adi' are small mountains that are not named.

In this Yalil is a large spring emerging from inside the sand, among the freshest of springs and most abundant in water. It flows in sand, so it does not enable cultivators [to farm] upon it except in few places (2) in the bends of the sand. In it are palms, and vegetables and melons are grown. This spring is called (Al-Buhayr (3)).

(Al-Jar (4)) [Saudi Arabia] is on the shore of the sea. Ships anchor there from the land of Abyssinia [Ethiopia] and Egypt [Egypt], and from Bahrain [Bahrain/Eastern Arabia] and China [China]. It has a pulpit and is a large populated village. Its people's drinking water is from Al-Buhayr. In Al-Jar are many palaces. Half of Al-Jar is on an island in the sea, [and half of it is on the coast. Opposite Al-Jar is an island in the sea (5)] about a mile by a mile, which is not crossed to
foot_note:
1. It is also called "Al-Sufayra". 'Asil ibn Ghaziyah said:
Then we poured down the mountains of Al-Sufr turning away ... from the left, and on our rights were Jubad.
He meant the mountains of Al-Safra, but the meter did not fit for him so he pluralized it and what followed it. Al-Bakri 836.
2. In the original: "kathirah" (many), corrected from Al-Bakri 836 and Yaqut under (Al-Buhayr, Yalil).
3. And so in Yaqut. In Al-Bakri 826: "Al-Buhayrah".
4. The origin of "Al-Jar" is what is close to the houses from the coast, as in Al-Lisan. Yaqut said: A city on the coast of the Sea of Qulzum [Red Sea], between it and Medina is a day and a night, and between it and Ayla is about ten stages, and to the coast of Al-Juhfah is about three stages. In the original: "wal-khabaw".
5. This necessary completion is from Yaqut and Al-Bakri under (Al-Jar). The Erudite Al-Maymani did not notice this completion.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text:
except (1) in ships. It is a port (2) for Abyssinia specifically. [It is called (3)] (Ghuraf). Its inhabitants are merchants like (4) the people of Al-Jar. They are brought water from two farsakhs away. The valley of Yalil pours into the sea (5).

Then from the left bank of Ghayqah towards (6) Medina on the right of one ascending to Mecca from Medina, and on the left of one ascending from Al-Sham [Levant] to Mecca, are two mountains called (Thafil al-Akbar) and (Thafil al-Asghar) [Mount Thafil/Jabal Subh, Saudi Arabia]. They belong to Damrah (7) specifically. They are people of Halal (settlements) (8), grazing (9), and wealth. Between them is a pass not the distance of an arrow shot. Between them and Radwa and Azwar is two nights. Their vegetation is 'Ar'ar (Juniper), Qaraz, Zayyan, Ayda', and Basham. The Zayyan has a thick stem, and it is thorny - meaning thick with thorns - and is used for firewood. It has a pod like the pod of the 'Ashraq. The Sanfah (pod): what hangs down from the fruit and exits from its branches. 'Ashraq: leaves resembling Handaquqa (Sweet Clover), foul-smelling.

The Ayda': a tree resembling the Dulb (Plane tree) (1). Except that its branches are closer together than the branches of the Dulb. It has a red flower that you do not find to have a good scent (2), and it has no fruit. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade breaking any of its branches, or [those of] the Sidr (Lote tree), the Tandub, and the Shubhan (3), because all of these possess shades in which people dwell (4) from the cold and heat.

The Tandub (5) has a fruit called Hamqa', resembling the Apricot (6), eaten and sweet. The Sarh (7) has a fruit called A' (8), resembling the Banana and sweeter than it, bearing very much fruit.
foot_note:
1. This word is established in the original, but Al-Maymani thought it missing so he established it in brackets.
2. In the original: "barih", corrected from Al-Bakri. In Yaqut: "marsa" (anchorage).
3. Completion from Yaqut and Al-Bakri.
4. In the original: "al-bahr" (the sea), corrected from Yaqut in (Al-Jar, Furat). Al-Bakri's phrase: "and likewise the inhabitants of Al-Jar".
5. Al-Bakri said: "This is Al-Sakuni's statement, but the correct [view] is that Yalil pours into Ghayqah, and Ghayqah pours into the sea."
6. This word is missing from Al-Maymani's copy.
7. Damrah ibn Bakr ibn Abd Manaf ibn Kinanah ibn Khuzaymah ibn Mudrikah, as mentioned by Yaqut in (Thafil). He said in its derivation: "Al-Thafl in the language: what settles (thafala) of everything." Al-Bakri vocalized it with Kasra on the Fa and Fatha.
8. Al-Halal: plural of Hillah, with Kasra, which is a group of people's houses, because they settle (tahullu). Kura' said: It is one hundred houses.
9. Al-Ra'iyah, with Kasra: a noun from Ra'y (grazing), as in Al-Lisan from Al-Lihyani. In the original: "wa da'ah", and in Yaqut: "wa raghbah", and Al-Bakri: "wa ra'a". I established what the comparison of readings requires.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
