text:
The Ayda': a tree resembling the Dulb (Plane tree) (1). Except that its branches are closer together than the branches of the Dulb. It has a red flower that you do not find to have a good scent (2), and it has no fruit. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade breaking any of its branches, or [those of] the Sidr (Lote tree), the Tandub, and the Shubhan (3), because all of these possess shades in which people dwell (4) from the cold and heat.

The Tandub (5) has a fruit called Hamqa', resembling the Apricot (6), eaten and sweet. The Sarh (7) has a fruit called A' (8), resembling the Banana and sweeter than it, bearing very much fruit.
foot_note:
1. Abu Hanifa: Al-Dulb: a tree that grows huge and wide, having no blossom or fruit. It has serrated, wide leaves resembling grape leaves, singular Dulbah. Yaqut said: Linguists other than 'Arram ibn al-Asbagh differ regarding Al-Ayda'. Some said it is Saffron, citing Ru'bah's saying:
As a pilgrim in Ihram avoids Ayda' ...
Some say: It is Dragon's Blood (Damm al-Akhawayn). Some said it is Brazilwood (Bakkam). The correct view to us is 'Arram's statement, because he is a Bedouin from those lands, and he knows the trees of his land best. An excellent witness to 'Arram's statement is Kuthayyir's saying where he said:
As if the loads of the people when they departed ... were a cut branch of palm or a cut branch of Ayda'
2. Yaqut: "not of good scent".
3. This word is missing from Yaqut. It is with Fatha on Sheen and Ba, or Damma: a type of 'Idah.
4. Yaqut: "dunaha" (under them).
5. In the original: "wa lil-sidr" (and for the Sidr), a distortion. The known fruit of the Sidr is Nabq. As for "Al-Hamqa'" with Damma on Ha and Fatha on Meem, lightened or stressed, it is the fruit of the Tandub, singular Hamqa'ah, as in Al-Lisan and Al-Mukhassas (11: 188). Indeed, Kura' said: The Hamqa' is the Tandub itself. Yaqut did not mention this phrase, but Al-Bakri mentioned it in (Arthad).
6. Ibn Durayd doubted the correctness of its Arabic origin. It is with Kasra on both Meems, or Fatha, or Damma, as in Taj al-Arus. Dawud al-Antaki, died year 1008, mentioned that what is called "Qamar al-Din" is made from it.
7. This is a digression by him, otherwise it was not mentioned before. Al-Sarh: plural of Sarhah, which are large, huge trees under which people settle in summer and build houses.
8. In the original: "al-laska". The known fruit of the Sarh is "Al-A'", singular "A'ah". In Al-Mukhassas (11: 189): The Sarh has a grape called Al-A', singular A'ah, which people eat and prepare rob (thick juice) from. It first has a bud (baramah) in which this A' comes out, and it resembles the Olive. There is no contradiction between 'Arram comparing it to the Olive and Ibn Sidah comparing it to the Banana, for one resemblance might be for shape and the other for taste.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: And in Thafil al-Akbar (Greater Thafil) there are several wells in the belly of a valley called (Yarthad). The wells are called (Al-Dabab), and it is abundant fresh water that is never exhausted; they are *anashit* (1) [shallow], the depth of a stature each. In Thafil al-Asghar (Lesser Thafil), there is water in a round tract of land in its hollow called (Al-Qahah (2)); they are two fresh, abundant wells. They are two large, towering mountains, and all the mountains of Tihamah grow *Ghadur*. Between them and Radwa and Azwar is seven stages (3). Between these mountains are small mountains and *qaradid* (4), and what is adjacent to each mountain is attributed to it. For one returning from [Medina] ascending [towards Mecca], the first mountain he encounters on his left is (Warqan (5)). It is a great black mountain, as great as mountains can be, extending from Sayalah to Al-Muta'asha (6) between Al-Arj and Al-Ruwaythah. Al-Muta'asha is also called Al-Jayy (7). In Warqan, there are all types (8) of fruit-bearing trees [and non-fruit-bearing (9)], and in it are Acacia (*Qaraz*),
foot_note:
1. Plural of *Nashat*. A well is called *Nashat* meaning near the bottom [shallow], from which the bucket comes out with a single pull.
2. The meaning of *Al-Qahah* and *Al-Bahah* is the same, which is the middle of the house. Yaqut said: 'Al-Qahah has been mentioned in it with Fa' and Jim [Al-Fahah/Al-Jahah].' It is mentioned in the books of Seerah regarding the 'Farewell Pilgrimage'. See *Imta' al-Asma'* 512. It was also mentioned in the path of the Hijrah. See *Al-Seerah* 333 Gottingen.
3. Plural of *Qardad*, which is what has risen from the earth and become hard.
4. In my first edition, it appeared as: 'wa Azwar wa Yanbu' marahil', which was a mistake of mine in reading the manuscript. Al-Maymani read it correctly as I have established here, and Sheikh Hamad mentioned it in his corrections. He pointed out that it is so in Al-Bakri's dictionary, under entry (Thafil).
5. With a Fatha on the first letter and a Kasra on the second, as Al-Bakri and Yaqut recorded it. Yaqut said: It is also narrated with a Sukun on the Ra'. Jamil recited: O my two friends, indeed Buthayna departed ... The day of Warqan, leaving the heart plundered. I say: Only poetic necessity permitted this change.
6. Neither Yaqut nor Al-Bakri created an entry for it, but they mentioned it in the entry of (Warqan).
7. Yaqut created an entry for it, but Al-Bakri did not; rather he created an entry for Jayy with a Fatha on the Jim, which is the city of Isfahan.
8. This word fell out of Al-Maymani's copy.
9. The completion is from Yaqut, Al-Bakri, and Al-Samhudi 2: 390. The scholar Al-Maymani did not include it.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: Sumac (1), Pomegranate, and *Khazam* (2). The people of Hijaz call Sumac 'Al-Dhamkh (3)' and the people of Najd (4) call it 'Al-Artan', the singular is *Artanah* (5). *Khazam* is a tree whose leaves resemble the leaves of papyrus (*Bardi*), and it has a trunk like the trunk of a palm tree, from which excellent ropes are made. In it [Warqan] are water seepages (*awshal*), springs, and rock pools (*qilat*). Its inhabitants are Aws from Muzaynah, people of columns [tent-dwellers] and wealth, and they are a truthful people. At its foot on the right is (Sayalah (6)), then (Al-Rawha (7)), then (Al-Ruwaythah (8)), then (Al-Jayy). Above it (9) between it and White Quds is a mountain path, or rather a pass (10), called (Rakubah).
foot_note:
1. Dawud said: A tree approaching the pomegranate in height, except that its leaves are downy and delicate. Abu Hanifa said: It has sour fruit in clusters containing small grains that are cooked. He said: I do not know of it growing in any of the land of the Arabs except what was in Al-Sham [Levant]. But Arram's text contradicts Abu Hanifa's statement. Among the districts of Aleppo is a great mountain called 'Jabal al-Summaq' due to the abundance of what grows in it.
2. Abu Hanifa: *Khazam*: A tree exactly like the Doum palm, having branches and small unripe dates that turn black when ripe; it is bitter and astringent, people do not eat it but crows are greedy for it and frequent it. See Arram's explanation that follows.
3. In the original: 'Al-Dhabh', a corruption, its correction is in Al-Bakri.
4. Al-Bakri: 'And the people of Al-Janad'.
5. In the original: 'Artunah', and this would only be a singular for 'Artun' like 'Zarjun', which is one of many dialects for 'Artan' mentioned in *Al-Lisan* and *Al-Qamus*.
6. Its mosque: One of three mosques built during the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), the second is the Mosque of Al-Harrah, and the third is the Mosque of Al-Shajarah. As for other mosques, they are places where he (peace be upon him) prayed, which were taken as mosques after him.
7. Urwah bin Hizam says about it (Al-Amali 3: 158): Oh, bear me, may Allah bless you both ... To the settled folk of Al-Rawha, then leave me.
8. Diminutive of *Rawthah*, which is a single piece of animal dung, or the *rawthah* (tip) of the nose.
9. The scholar Al-Maymani read it 'yaflis', but its script in the original does not support that. In Al-Samhudi 2: 390: 'yafsil' (separates).
10. *Thaniyah*: The road of the *Aqabah* (pass). Abu Mansur said: *Aqab*: Tall mountains crossing the road, so the road takes through them. Every traveled pass is a *Thaniyah*, and its plural is *Thanaya*.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: And (Quds (1)), this is a towering mountain extending to Al-Muta'asha between Al-Arj and Al-Suqya, then it is cut off (2) between it and Black Quds by a pass called (Hamat). The vegetation of both Quds mountains is Juniper (*Ar'ar*), Acacia (*Qaraz*), *Shawhat*, and *Shaqb* (3): a tree having shoots resembling the ridges on a sword (4), from which bows are made. Both Quds mountains belong to Muzaynah, and their wealth is livestock of sheep (5) and camels; they are people of columns [tent-dwellers]. There are many water seepages in them. Facing them (6) from the right (7) of the ascending road are two mountains called (Nahban): Lower Nahb and Upper Nahb. They belong to Muzaynah, and Banu Layth have a share in them. Their vegetation is Juniper and *Ithrar* (8). Tar may be made from *Ithrar* just as it is made from Juniper; and in them is Acacia (*Qaraz*). They are high, towering, and large. In Upper Nahb there is water in a round tract of land, a single large well with abundant water, upon which are melon patches (9), vegetables, and small palm trees (10), called (Dhu Khayma (11)), and in it are water seepages.
foot_note:
1. Al-Anbari said: Quds is feminine and does not decline (*la tujra*) - meaning it is diptote - a name for the mountain and what is around it. But Arram treated it as triptote here as will follow. Al-Bakri also treated it as triptote in the entry of (Arah).
2. In the original: 'sa'ta' with unpointed letters.
3. With a vowel on the second letter or a Kasra. Al-Maymani made it 'Al-Sakb', which is an oversight by him.
4. *Al-Usru'*: The shoot, which is what grows around the tree from its base. *Al-Shatbah*: The ridge of the sword prominent on its blade.
5. Thus in the original, Al-Maymani made it 'Al-Sha'' (sheep/goats).
6. In the original: 'yuqabiluha' (faces her/it).
7. Al-Maymani read it thus despite it being unpointed in the original. Sheikh Hamad believes the correct reading is 'yamin' (right).
8. Its explanation will come on page 408.
9. Plural of *mabtakhah*, a place for melons.
10. Al-Maymani made it 'nakhalat' (palms), and there is no need for this change.
11. Thus in Yaqut under entry 'Nahban' and Al-Zamakhshari in Kitab al-Jibal 166-167 and in Al-Bakri under his entry and in (Quds 1052), and likewise Al-Hamdani in Sifat Jazirat al-Arab 176 'Dhu Khaym'. But in Al-Bakri under entry (Al-Arj): 'Al-Munbajis'.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: In Lower Nahb there are *Awshan* (1), and the road separates them from Quds and Warqan, and in it is (Al-Arj). The valley of Al-Arj is called (Masihah (2)), its vegetation is *Markh*, *Arak*, and *Thumam*. On the left of the road facing Black Quds (3) is a mountain of the highest height, called (Arah). It is a red mountain from whose sides springs burst forth (4); at every spring is a village. Among them is a large, lush village called (Al-Fara' (5) [Al Fara, Saudi Arabia]), which belongs to Quraysh, the Ansar, and Muzaynah. And among them is (Umm al-Iyal (6)), a village that is the charitable endowment (*sadaqah*) of Fatimah, daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him (7). Above it is a village called (Al-Madiq (8)). And among them is a village called (Al-Mahdah (9)), and a village called (Al-Wabrah (10)), and a village called (Khadrah (11)), and a village
foot_note:
1. Al-Maymani thought it was missing from the original, but it is fixed in it.
2. Thus in Al-Bakri in 'Quds' quoting Al-Sakuni. In the original: 'Fasihah', a corruption. Yaqut mentioned in (Samihah) three dialects, said with diminutive, magnification, and placing the Mim first as here.
3. Thus the quotation from him appeared in Yaqut in the entry 'Arah'. See what preceded on p. 403.
4. Thus in the original and Al-Samhudi 2: 239. In Yaqut: 'takhruju' (come out) and Al-Bakri: 'tanfajiru' (explode/burst). I had read it in my first edition 'takhruju'.
5. Pronounced with one Damma or two Dammas, as Yaqut mentioned.
6. Al-Bakri: 'Land in Al-Fara' belonging to Ja'far bin Talhah bin Amr bin Ubayd Allah bin Uthman bin Ka'b. Talhah was beautiful and handsome, so he stuck to the cultivation of the spring of Umm al-Iyal, which has great value. He stayed there and was struck by the epidemic, so he came to [Medina] having changed. Anas bin Malik saw him and said: This is the one who built his wealth and ruined his body.' See Yaqut (1: 336).
7. Similar to what appeared in Al-Bakri 1329 that 'Al-Jathjathah: charity of Abdullah bin Hamza'. And what appeared in 743 'and many of them - i.e., the springs - are charities of Al-Hasan bin Zayd'. See a form of donating estates as charity in Al-Bakri 658.
8. Yaqut mentioned that Banu Amir and their chief Alqama bin Ulatha raided Zayd al-Khayl, so they met at Al-Madiq. Zayd al-Khayl captured them to the last man, and among them was Al-Hutay'ah, who complained to him of poverty, so he bestowed favor upon him.
9. From their saying 'mahada al-shay'', meaning purified it, as Yaqut mentioned.
10. Named after the animal (*Wabr* - Hyrax), which is a small dust-colored creature the size of a cat, with beautiful eyes and intense shyness, found in the Ghor.
11. Thus vocalized in Yaqut and Al-Bakri in its entry, and Al-Bakri also mentioned it in (Quds 1051). In the original: 'Hadrah' with an unpointed Ha, a corruption.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: called (Al-Faghwah (1)) surrounding Arah from all its sides. In all these villages are palm trees and crops. It is three stages from Al-Suqya to its left towards the sunrise. Its valley flows into (Al-Abwa [Al Abwa, Saudi Arabia]), then into (Waddan), which is a village (2) among the mother villages of Damrah, Kinanah, Ghifar, and Fihr Quraysh, then into (Al-Tarifah [on the Red Sea coast]). Al-Tarifah is a village, not large, on the seashore. The name of the valley of Arah is (Haql (3)), and [there is] a village called (Wab'an (4)). (Khalas Arah (5)) is a valley containing villages, *ajza'* (6) [winding parts of a valley], and palms. The poet (7) said about it:
foot_note:
1. It is from *Al-Faghwah*, meaning the flower.
2. This word fell out of Al-Maymani's edition, but it is fixed in the original.
3. In Al-Bakri in his entry and in (Quds 1052): 'Haqil'. I established it in my first edition as 'Haqil', and the correction is by Sheikh Hamad conforming to what is in the original and Mu'jam al-Buldan 3: 306. Al-Samhudi in Wafa' al-Wafa 2: 292 said: 'As for Haqil, it is in Najd. And there is a vast distance between the two places.'
4. Yaqut and Al-Bakri created entries for it, and it is with a Fatha on the Waw and Kasra on the Ba. Al-Bakri erred when he created another entry for it as (Wan'an) with a Fatha on the Waw and Nun, and referred to places where it was mentioned correctly.
5. Nusayb says about it, as Al-Bakri narrated: And she used to dwell in the Arak trees of Khalas ... To the winding parts of Bishah and Al-Ragham.
6. Plural of *Jaz'*, with a Kasra, which is the side of the valley and where it bends; it is said it is not called *Jaz'* until it has width that grows trees and other things.
7. He is Abu al-Muzahim, as Al-Bakri mentioned in 449-450. The verses are in Yaqut (Khalas, Wab'an) and Al-Bakri 450, 1052. Sheikh Hamad wrote a precious comment here, and this is its text: 'Perhaps it benefits the readers to transfer some news of its sayer from the book (Al-Ta'liqat wa al-Nawadir by Abu Ali al-Hajari - Egyptian National Library copy). He said: And recited to me by 'Azlan al-Thumami, from Thumamah bin Ka'b bin Judhaymah bin Khafaf: My two friends, divert me and my saddle and my she-camel ... To Mulah al-Rayyan then leave me. If you two do not do so and pass ... By the garden of Al-Zaydi then bid me farewell. I ask about 'Umq and the goodness of its state ... And were it not for the daughter of Al-Zaydi my questioning would be little. 'Umq al-Zuru' is near Al-Fara', and 'Umq al-Madiq is by Yalyal near Badr. He said: The Zaydis are from Banu Imran -

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: If at Khalas then Al-Burayra then Al-Hasha ... Then Wakad to Al-Naq'a from Wab'an (1)
foot_note:
1. - from Muzaynah then from Banu Uthman. And Al-Dahna: A water pit between Marr 'Unayb and Al-Sa'irah. And he has: Visit 'Umq Dhi al-Zuru' and greet ... Even if it deviates from the intended path of the mounts. For indeed in 'Umq Dhi al-Zuru' there is an idol ... Of Aslam, speaking to them brings rewards. Do not be incapable of a need for your brother ... Even if it involves harshness and immorality. What harm would it do if the clan of the Aslamiyyah women appeared ... To us on the day of 'Umq of arms and chests. And regarding the wedding of Qannan I have an oath ... And regarding the beautiful Hanzhi women there are vows. And he has regarding Muzani women: If at Wakad then Al-Burayra then Al-Hasha ... Then Khalas to Al-Ranqa' from Wab'an. Wakad: A black edge behind Marr by Shawkan. Al-Burayra: A small hillock. Al-Hasha: A land between Marr and Shawkan, and Khalas Arah. Al-Ranqa' here: A lowland. Wab'an is in the Harrah. Friendly women from the tribe of 'Ada', both of them ... Aspiring with husbands, not singing women. They were driven mad with a madness from husbands as if they were ... Monkeys jumping in Yemeni robes. So pass and say 'Two seekers of a need' ... And return and say 'We are departing'. So they caught him in Al-Dahna - which is a deep water pit - and tied a millstone to his leg then threw him into it, so he perished. He said: This is what I transferred from the book of Al-Hajari, I cited it at length because it includes something related to the sayer of those verses. But is he Abu al-Muzahim to whom Al-Bakri attributed the verses? It appears he is: The author of Al-Taj recited one of them under entry (Waba'a) and attributed it to Abu al-Muzahim al-Sa'di. Al-Asbahani narrated in Al-Aghani Vol 11 p 79 two verses by Abu al-Muzahim, which are: They reproached me that Sulaym called me their brother ... And Sa'd gave me their oaths. It is understood from them that this Muzahim is a Sa'di who allied with Sulaym and was counted among them. Al-Hajari mentioned that the owner of the verses is Thumami from Thumamah bin Ka'b bin Judhaymah bin Khafaf. It is known that Khafaf is a clan of Sulaym. As for knowing the era of this poet, it is known from his being a contemporary of Abu Wajzah al-Sa'di the poet. This Abu Wajzah is a Tabi'i (Successor), meaning from the Islamic poets. And Al-Hajari who narrated the verses of the Epistle is from the people of the second and third Hijri centuries.'
1. Its beginning in Al-Bakri: 'If at the winding valleys', and in the original: 'Fawwalad' corruption, its correction is in Yaqut in both places. Al-Bakri narrated 'Nukaz' and 'Farqad'. And 'Al-Naq'a' is the narration of the original and Yaqut in the entry (Wab'an), which is a place behind [Medina], and in Al-Bakri 1052 'Al-Baq'a' with Ba, which is from the land of Rukbah. And in 450 he has 'Al-Naq'ayn'.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: Maidens from the tribe of 'Ada' as if they were ... Wild cows of the sand possessing mates, not captives (1) / Driven mad with a madness by husbands as if they were ... Monkeys, competing in Yemeni robes (2). Then connected [to Khalas Arah (3)] is (Dharah (4)), which are many connected mountains, *Da'adi'* (5) [small mountains] not towering. In their peaks (6) are farms and villages; they belong to Banu al-Harith bin Bahtha bin Sulaym. Their crops are rain-fed (*A'dha'*). They call the *A'dha'* 'Al-Athari': which is that which is not irrigated [artificially]. In it are mud houses, but most of them are tents. They have springs of [water (7)] in rocks which they cannot conduct (8) to where they can utilize it (9). They have trees of *Afar*, Acacia (*Qaraz*), *Talh*, Lote trees (*Sidr*) are abundant there, *Nashm*, and *Ta'alb* (10).
foot_note:
1. 'Ada' can be a verbal noun like 'Mu'adah' (enmity), and this tribe was described by it, or it can be the elongated form of 'Al-Uda' meaning enemies, elongated for poetry. In Al-Bakri 1052: 'Hayy 'Ada'', dual of Hayy (tribe). In Yaqut in (Wab'an): 'Husna ghadha' corruption. Describing the sand as having pairs refers to pairs of wild animals like cows and gazelles. Al-Awani: plural of 'An and 'Aniyah, which is the captive.
2. The word 'tubari' is unpointed in the original despite the clarity of its letters, its reading is from Yaqut (Wab'an). In Yaqut (Khalas): 'tunadi'.
3. The completion is from Yaqut (Dharah) from Arram. Al-Maymani did not establish it.
4. With a Fatha on the first and lightening the second [Dharah], as in Yaqut. Al-Bakri entered it as 'Dharwah' with Fatha on the first and Sukun on the second with the addition of Waw, and quoted Al-Sakuni's text therein.
5. Explained previously on p. 398.
6. 'Al-Dhura' explained previously on p. 397. In the original and Al-Maymani's copy: 'duraha' instead of 'fi dhuraha', corrected in Yaqut.
7. Completion from Yaqut and Al-Bakri.
8. Thus in Yaqut. In Al-Bakri: 'ijra'uha'.
9. This word fell out of our first edition.
10. Mentioned in dictionaries under (Alb) and (Ta'alb). Ibn Sidah said: Ta'alb is among the best woods from which bows are made, its habitats are the mountains of Yemen, and it has clusters like clusters of the terebinth. When it matures and dries, it is pressed for lamps, and it is better for them than oil. The caterpillar falls on the Ta'alb tree and strips it of its leaves. Al-Mukhassas (11: 142).

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: Bows and arrows are sometimes made from *Nashm*; it consists of branches (*khaytan*) with no leaves (1). *Ithrar* (2) has leaves resembling thyme leaves and thorns like pomegranate thorns; its fire is struck (3) when it is dry, so it ignites quickly. *Afar* has white blossoms with a pleasant scent like lily (*Sawsan*) (4). Surrounding Dharah is a village called (Jabalah) to its west (5), and (Al-Sittarah) is a village connected to Jabalah. Their valley is one, called (Lahf (6)), and it has springs. They claim that Jabalah is the first village established in Tihamah. In Jabalah there are formidable fortresses built with rocks that no one dares attack. To the east of Dharah is a village called (Al-Qa'r) and a village called (Al-Shar' (7)); both are eastern. In each of these villages are farms and palms on springs. They are on a valley called (Rakhim). At its bottom is a village called (Dhar'aa) containing palaces (8), a pulpit (*minbar*), and fortresses.
foot_note:
1. Ibn Sidah did not add in Al-Mukhassas (11: 142) in describing Nashm more than it is of the best woods. In Al-Lisan: A mountain tree from which bows are made, and it is of the best woods. And (*khaytan*) here is the plural of *khut*, with Damma not *khayt* with Fatha. *Khut*: The tender branch. He recited in Al-Lisan (Khut): Oh, how lovely is the sound of the Ghadha tree when a south wind ... rustles its branches (*khaytan*) after sleep. The scholar Al-Maymani thought it was an error and made it 'idan' (sticks) instead of 'khaytan', which is an oversight by him.
2. With Kasra on the Hamza as in Al-Qamus and Al-Lisan. In Al-Qamus it is called (Al-Anbarbaris) and in Al-Lisan it is called in Persian (Al-Zarik), correctly (Zirishk) as in Tadhkirat Dawud in entry (Ambaris) and Steingass dictionary 615.
3. The word is unpointed in the original. Al-Maymani read it 'tarah' and it is not so.
4. Dawud said: It is in Greek 'Iris', meaning rainbow, due to the varying colors in the flower.
5. 'In its west' fell out of Al-Maymani's edition.
6. With Fatha on the Lam as Yaqut stated in its entry.
7. Yaqut said: Derived from *shara'a al-ihab* (skinning the hide), if it is split and not skinned as a bag or from the legs. It is the widest method of skinning.
8. In the original: 'qaryah biha laha sar'a yadur', and its correction is in Yaqut under entry 'Dhar'aa'.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: Hudhayl (1) and Ghadirah bin Sa'sa'ah (2) share it with Banu al-Harith. Then connected [to it] is (Shamansir), which is a smooth, round mountain (3) that no one has ever ascended, nor is it known what is on its summit; at its top are monkeys. It is said: Most of its vegetation is *Nab'*, *Shawhat*, and the waters around it are springs (4) with palms and wild figs (*Hamat*) (5). In all the mountains of Tihamah there is *Shaqah* (6), a plant in its *Harud* (7) and lower parts - and *Harud* (8): the sides. *Hamat*: Fig. *Shaqah*: *Ribas* (9). Surrounding Shamansir among the villages is a large village called (Rahat (10)), which is in a valley called (Ghuran (11)). He recited:
foot_note:
1. Yaqut: 'Yashtarik bayn al-Harith fiha Hudhayl', and this is a corruption. These Banu al-Harith are Banu al-Harith bin Bahtha bin Sulaym, as preceded on p. 407.
2. Ghadirah: A clan from Banu Ghalib bin Sa'sa'ah bin Mu'awiyah bin Bakr bin Hawazin. Taj al-Arus 3: 450. It appeared in my first edition as 'Amir bin Sa'sa'ah' due to a reading error. It is correct in Al-Maymani's edition.
3. *Al-Mulamlam*: The round, gathered together.
4. 'And the waters around it are springs' fell out of Al-Maymani's edition.
5. *Al-Hamat*: Mountain fig tree. In the original 'Al-Hamad' here and in the following place. The correct is what I established.
6. In the original here and in what follows 'Al-Shaqh' is a corruption. He interpreted it later as 'Al-Ribas'. *Al-Shaqah*, like 'Rumman': the Caper plant, as in Al-Lisan. In Al-Mu'tamad by Ibn Rasul al-Ghassani 282: 'And the Caper that is in the very hot country is like the Caper that is in Tihamah'. And *Al-Ribas* is a Persian word, Steingass said in his dictionary 601 interpreting it: A Sour herb. It applies to Caper and *Shaqah*.
7. *Al-Hurud*: The edges of the mountain. As in Al-Qamus (Harad). In the original here: 'Haruzuha' and in what follows 'Al-Harur', the correct is what I established.
8. 'And its lower parts and the *Harud* are the sides', all fell out of Al-Maymani's copy.
9. See footnote number 6.
10. With Damma on the Ra'. Ibn al-Kalbi said: 'Hudhayl took Suwa' as a lord in Rahat'.
11. In Al-Bakri in (Shamansir): 'Ghurab', a corruption. He said in (Ghuran): 'Fa'al from *Al-Gharin*, and *Al-Gharin* and *Al-Gharil* is the mud from which water recedes and dries at the bottom of the pond'.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: For indeed Ghuran is the belly of a valley I love ... To its inhabitant, there is a firm covenant upon me (1) / To its west is a village called (Al-Hudaybiyah [Al Hudaybiyah, Saudi Arabia] (2)), not large, and opposite it is a small mountain called (Da'adi'). Near it is a large dam (*Habs*) where water collects. A *Habs*: stones gathered and placed one upon another. The poet said: / And indeed my turning towards the dam of (Da'adi') ... And the turning of my eye towards Al-Zuba is long (3) / These small villages belong to Sa'd and Banu Masruh, and they are the ones among whom the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, grew up. Hudhayl has something in them, and Fahm as well. Their waters are *Buthur*, which are shallow wells (*Ahsa'*) and springs, not deep wells (4). From Al-Hudaybiyah to [Medina] is nine stages, and to [Mecca] is a stage and a mile or two miles. To the right of Arah is the road for the ascender (Al-Hasha (5)), which is the mountain of (Al-Abwa [Al Abwa, Saudi Arabia]). It is in a valley called (Al-Ba'q), a valley on its left flank [a valley] called (7) (Shass). It is a land of thirst and epidemic (8), camels cannot survive there; thirst (*Hiyam*) overtakes them from stagnant waters in it
foot_note:
1. 'uhibbuhu' (I love it), is what is in Al-Bakri. In the original: 'habbahu' with neglect [unpointed]. In Yaqut 'Jannah' (garden). And 'covenant' is in Yaqut and Al-Bakri: 'Aqd'.
2. With lightening of the Ya and stressing it. Named after a humped tree that was in that place. In the Hadith, it is a well. Some of Al-Hudaybiyah is in the Hill (profane territory) and some in the Haram (sanctuary).
3. Yaqut: 'Aynayya al-Zuba' with dual eyes. Al-Zuba: A valley in Tihamah. In the original: 'Ayni fi al-siba', and in Al-Bakri: 'Ayni al-saba', both corrupt.
4. In the original: 'laysat biha' (not in it), corrected from Al-Bakri 810. See what will come regarding the discussion on *Al-Buthur* before the discussion on 'The Border of Hijaz'.
5. Al-Bakri: 'And Al-Hasha belongs to Khuza'ah and Damrah'.
6. *Al-Kanaf* and *Al-Kanafa*: The side of the thing. Sheikh Hamad said: 'But in the original as I learned from the two copies compared against it: bi-kafatihi'. I assure the Sheikh that this knowledge is wrong, and that between the Kaf and the Fa in the original is a clear pointed Nun.
7. In the original: 'wa lahu', and the completion I established before from Al-Bakri 449 requires what I established.
8. *Mawba'ah*, with Fatha on the Mim: He meant full of epidemic (*waba'*), and this form was not stated in the dictionaries. In the original: 'Bawbah', the correct form is what I established from Yaqut in (Shams).

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: stagnant, not flowing (1) - *Al-Hiyam*: camel fever - It is a high, towering mountain with no vegetation of the earth except *Khazam* and *Basham*. It belongs to Khuza'ah and Damrah. The poet (2) said regarding Al-Ba'q: / As if you are relapsed in Shass, expelled ... The thirsty camels of the thicket of Al-Ba'q approach him (3) / And (Al-Abwa) is half a mile from it. Then (Harsha), which is in level land; it is a round hill that grows nothing. Below it is (Waddan) at two miles towards the sunset. The ascenders among the pilgrims of [Medina] cross it and pour down from it returning to [Mecca] (4). Connected to it towards the sunset on its right, between it and the sea, is a *Khabt* - *Khabt*: Sand that grows nothing but *Arta*, which is firewood, and milk skins are specifically tanned with it. In the middle of the *Khabt* is a small black mountain, intensely black, called (Tufayl). Then the mountains cease (5) from you on the right and left. On the road from the Pass of Harsha, between it and Al-Juhfah [near Rabigh, Saudi Arabia], are three named valleys:
foot_note:
1. *Sakirah* with Ra, meaning still. In Al-Lisan: 'Abu Zayd, *Al-Sakir*: That which does not flow, and *sakara sukurun*, and the sea became still (*sakara*): calmed. Ibn al-A'rabi recited describing a sea: * It vomits the foam of heat when it becomes still ... In Al-Bakri 449 and Yaqut (5: 262): 'Sakinah'.
2. It is Kuthayyir, as in Al-Bakri 796 and Yaqut in (Shass). Al-Bakri also narrated it in 449. Yaqut recited it in (Shass, Ba'q). Before it: And my two friends said the day we departed and ... Loops of the chest were opened and its seals broken / The arrows of the Hajibiyah struck you, indeed ... When she shoots, her wounded does not recover.
3. *Al-Mardu'*: The one who relapsed in his illness. *Yuqarifuhu*: Approaches him. *Al-Uqdah*: The wooded place.
4. In the original: 'from Mecca', corrected in Yaqut (Harsha).
5. In the original: 'Ind' (at).

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: Among them is (Ghazal (1)), which is a valley coming to you from the direction of Shamansir and Dharah. In it is well water, and it belongs specifically to Khuza'ah, who are its inhabitants, people of columns [tents]. And (Dawran (2)), which is a valley coming to you also from Shamansir and Dharah; [in it] are two known wells, one called (Rahbah (3)) and the other (Sakubah). It belongs to Khuza'ah also. The third is (Kulayyah (4)), which is a valley coming to you also from Shamansir and Dharah. All these valleys grow *Arak*, *Markh*, *Doum* - which is *Muql* (Theban Palm) - and Palm trees. There are no mountains there. In Kulayyah, on the surface of the road, is well water; the wells are called Kulayyah, and the valley is named after them. At the top of this Kulayyah are three small isolated mountains called (Shanai'k (5)), and they belong to Khuza'ah.
foot_note:
1. In it is the saying of Kuthayyir, and Yaqut recited it: They took a midday nap at Usfan then departed quickly ... Rising in the evening from Ghazal.
2. In the original: 'Dhawran', corrected in Yaqut. He recited for Kuthayyir: She called you while the white camels were hurrying with us ... The descent of Dhu Dawran then Al-Qa'. It is also called 'Dhu Dawran' as in this poetry, and as in Al-Bakri 1352. The word 'Dhu' is added often in names of places, as they said: Dhu Athayl, Dhu Jusham, Dhu al-Arja, Dhat al-Alanda, and Dhat al-Isad.
3. Thus in Yaqut in (Dawran).
4. In diminutive form. It was the dwelling of Nusayb, and about it he says: My two friends, if you alight at Kulayyah then Al-Ruba ... Then Dha Amaj then the She'b (path) possessing water and sour plants.
5. Thus in Yaqut in its entry, he said: 'As if it is the plural of Shanukah including what is around it. Nasr said: Shanai'k: Three small isolated mountains between Qudayd and Al-Juhfah from the lands of Khuza'ah. It is said Shanukatan are two branches pouring into Al-Rawha between Mecca and Medina'. In Sifat Jazirat al-Arab 181: 'And Shanukatan pouring into Al-Rawha'. Yaqut said in entry (Shanukah): 'Shawkah: A mountain, and it is an improvised proper noun'. He recited for Kuthayyir: Like the purity of affection on the day of Shanukah ... And pledges from them overtook me. Al-Bakri made it 'Sanabik' and created an entry for it and in the entry of (Harsha), and said: 'Sanabik on the wording of plural of Sunbuk: gathered small mountains, mentioned in the entry of Harsha'.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: Below Al-Juhfah by a mile is (Ghadir Khumm (1) [Ghadir Khumm, Saudi Arabia]), and its valley pours into the sea. It grows nothing but *Markh*, *Thumam*, *Arak*, and *Ushar*. This Ghadir Khumm is towards the sunrise; water never leaves it from rainwater. In it are people from Khuza'ah and Kinanah, not many. Then (Al-Sharah (2)), which is a high mountain towering into the sky inhabited by monkeys. It grows *Nab'*, *Shawhat*, and *Qaraz*. It belongs specifically to Banu Layth and Banu Zafar from Banu Sulaym. It is below Usfan [Usfan, Saudi Arabia] on its left. In it is a pass that goes to the region of Hijaz for one traveling via Usfan, called (Al-Kharitah), ascending and very high. Al-Kharitah which is next to Al-Sharah is a hard [smooth (3)] mountain that grows nothing. Then one overlooks from Al-Sharah (Sayah), which is a valley between two *Hamiyahs* (4), which are two black Harrahs (lava fields). In it are many named villages and many roads from many directions. The highest of them is a village called (Al-Fari') containing many palms. Its inhabitants are from all mixed groups of people (5). Its waters are springs flowing underground, all of them are *Fuqar* (underground channels). *Fiqr* and *Qana* (6) are the same, and the singular of *Fuqar* is *Faqir*.
foot_note:
1. Al-Bakri mentioned that the one who dug it was 'Abd Shams', as he also dug 'Zamma'. About them he says: I dug Khumm and I dug Zamma ... Until you see the glory for us has been completed. Al-Fakihi said in Kitab Makkah: 'People used to come to Khumm in Jahiliyyah and Islam in the early era, promenading in it and staying in it.' At it, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, gave a sermon and said regarding Ali, peace be upon him: 'Whomever I am his master, Ali is his master', Shuruh Saqt al-Zand 389.
2. With a Fatha on the Shin (dotted) and ending with Ha, as in the original and Yaqut. In Al-Bakri: 'Shara'' and he said: 'Elongated, diptote because it is a name of a land. This is the saying of Abu Ubaydah. Al-Asma'i said it has a Kasra on the end like Hadhami and Qatami'.
3. Completion from Al-Bakri. *Al-Jald* with movement: Hard. *Al-Sald* with Fatha: That which does not grow plants.
4. In Al-Lisan: 'Al-Hawami: Great stones and heavy ones, singular Hamiyah'.
5. *Afna' al-nas*: Their mixtures, plural of *finw* with Kasra, weighed like *fata*.
6. Plural of *Qanat* dug for water, also pluralized as *Qunan*, *Fu'ul*.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: Then below it is (Mahayi' (1)), which is a large lush village (2). It has many people and a pulpit (*minbar*). The governor of Sayah is from the ruler of [Medina]. In it are palms, farms, bananas, pomegranates, and grapes. Its origin belongs to the descendants of Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him. In it are mixed groups of people and merchants from every land. Then a *Khayf* called (Khayf Salam (3)). A *Khayf*: What is set aside from the waterway to the right and left, widening out. In it is a pulpit and many people from Khuza'ah. Its waters are *Fuqar* (channels) as well. Its nomads are few, consisting of Jusham, Khuza'ah, and Hudhayl. This Salam (4) is a man from the wealthy of this land from the Ansar. Below that is (Khayf Dhi al-Qabr). It has no pulpit although it is populated. It has many palms, bananas, and pomegranates. Its inhabitants are Banu Masruh, Sa'd, and Kinanah (5), and diverse (6) merchants. Its water is *Fuqar* and springs issuing from both banks of the valley. It was named (Khayf Dhi al-Qabr) by the grave of Ahmad bin al-Rida (7), and it is famous for it.
foot_note:
1. Yaqut said: 'As if it is the plural of *Mahya'*, which is the wide road.
2. A lush (*ghanna'*) village: Abundant in inhabitants, buildings, and grass.
3. I read it in the first edition: 'wa walin yantabuhu' (and a governor frequents it), which is an error corrected by Sheikh Hamad conforming to Al-Maymani's reading in his copy.
4. Also said with lightening of the Lam in a saying mentioned by Yaqut in entry (Lawiyyah).
5. The Waw before 'Kinanah' fell out of Al-Maymani's edition; the correct is to establish it as in the original.
6. Meaning different/mixed, plural of *lifq* with Kasra, originally one of the two halves of a cloak. The word was written unpointed on the last letter in the original with a tendency towards curvature.
7. Al-Rida: The title of Ali bin Musa bin Ja'far bin Muhammad bin Ali bin Al-Husayn bin Ali bin Abi Talib Al-Hashimi, Abu Al-Hasan. His son Muhammad, Abu Uthman Al-Mazini the grammarian, Al-Ma'mun bin Al-Rashid and others narrated from him. He was martyred in Tus in the year 203. Tahdhib al-Tahdhib. Ibn Qutaybah mentioned in Al-Ma'arif 169 that Al-Ma'mun sent for Ali bin Musa Al-Rida, carried him to Khorasan, and pledged allegiance to him as Crown Prince after him, and ordered people to wear green. Muhammad bin Ali bin Hamza Al-Alawi mentioned that Al-Rida had no children, male or female, except Muhammad bin Ali bin Musa, and his grave is in Baghdad in the Quraysh cemeteries. Thus, what Arram mentioned here is an error. Al-Bakri 787. See the biography of (Muhammad bin al-Rida) in Tarikh Baghdad 997.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: Below it is (Khayf al-Ni'am (1)) which has a pulpit. Its people are Ghadirah and Khuza'ah, and merchants after that and people. It has palms and farms, and falls under the governor of Usfan. Its waters are many flowing springs. Then (Usfan [Usfan, Saudi Arabia]), which is on the surface of the road, belonging specifically to Khuza'ah. It has a pulpit, palms, and many farms. Then [if you depart from Usfan you encounter (2)] the sea, and mountains and villages leave you, except for named valleys between you and Marr al-Zahran. One valley is called Masihah (3) and a valley called (Madrakah (4)). They are two large valleys with much water and palms; among them is a water called (Al-Hudaybiyah) at its bottom. They pour from the tops of the Harrah (lava field) elongating to the sea. Then (Marr al-Zahran (5) [Wadi Fatimah, Saudi Arabia]). Marr is the village, and Al-Zahran is the valley. It has many springs, palms, and sycamore figs. It belongs to Aslam, Hudhayl, and Ghadirah. Then you exit it into (Bahrayn (6)), then you aim for [Mecca] descending from a pass called
foot_note:
1. Thus in Yaqut and Al-Qamus (Khayf). In Al-Bakri 787 'Khayf al-Nu'man'.
2. Completion from Yaqut in entry (Masihah, Al-Madrakah).
3. Yaqut created an entry for it. As for Al-Bakri, he mentioned it casually in 226, 1025. It was vocalized incorrectly in the last place. Al-Bakri and Yaqut recited for Abu Jundub al-Hudhali: To where are we driven when we have reached ... Thirsty, from Masihah, a shallow water.
4. In the original 'yuqal amdaraka' corruption. Yaqut created an entry for Al-Madrakah and vocalized it with Damma on Mim and Fatha on Ra. Not mentioned in Al-Bakri neither as entry nor casually.
5. Yaqut mentioned it is called 'Marr al-Zahran'. Kuthayyir Azzah said: It was named Marr for its bitterness (*mararah*). Abu Ghassan said: It was named so because in the belly of the valley between Marr and Nakhlah there is writing on a vein of the earth in white spelling (Marr) except the Mim is not connected to the Ra. Al-Bakri and Yaqut. Al-Bakri said: And in the belly of Marr, Khuza'ah was cut off (*takhazza'at*) from its brethren, so it remained in [Mecca] and its brethren went to Sham during the days of the flood of Al-Arim. Hassan said: When we descended the belly of Marr, separated ... Khuza'ah from us in encampments, the groups. Yaqut attributed the verse to Awn bin Ayyub al-Ansari.
6. Thus it appeared unpointed with this script. Al-Maymani read it 'tariq' (road), but the script of the original does not allow that.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: (Al-Jafjaf (1)). In Najd, at the border of [Mecca], is a valley (2) called (Wadi Turabah (3) [Turabah, Saudi Arabia]) pouring into (Bustan Ibn Amir (4)). The lower part of Turabah belongs to Banu Hilal. Surrounding it among the mountains are (Al-Sharah (5)), (Yasum), (Qarqad (6)), (Ma'dan al-Baram (7)), and two mountains called (Shawanan (8)),
foot_note:
1. With Fatha on both Jims. Yaqut said: 'It is in the language the wide, back-facing lowland'.
2. Yaqut: 'And you descend at the border of [Mecca] into a valley'. I preferred Yaqut's phrase in my first edition. Sheikh Hamad said commenting on Yaqut's phrase: 'But when we know the distance of Wadi Turabah from [Mecca], we can realize the flaw here'.
3. With Damma then Fatha, and similar in place names is 'Uranah' in [Mecca].
4. Al-Asma'i, Abu Ubaydah and others said: Bustan Ibn Amir actually belongs to Umar bin Ubayd Allah bin Ma'mar bin Uthman bin Amr bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Taym bin Murrah bin Ka'b bin Lu'ay bin Ghalib, but people erred and said Bustan Ibn Amir and Bustan Banu Amir, while it is Bustan Ibn Ma'mar. Some say: attributed to Hadrami bin Amir, and others say: attributed to Abdullah bin Amir bin Kurayz. All of that is conjecture and guessing. Al-Batalyawsi said in Al-Iqtidab: Bustan Ibn Ma'mar is different from Bustan Ibn Amir. As for Bustan Ibn Ma'mar, it is the one known as Batn Nakhlah, and Ibn Ma'mar is Umar bin Ubayd Allah bin Ma'mar al-Taymi. As for Bustan Ibn Amir, it is another place near Al-Juhfah, and this Ibn Amir is Abdullah bin Amir bin Kurayz. From Yaqut.
5. Yaqut: Al-Hijaz are mountains separating Tihamah and Najd. Their top is called Al-Sarat just as the back of a beast is called Al-Sarat. Al-Sarat: Mountains extending from Yemen to the outskirts of the deserts of Sham.
6. I found a comment by Sheikh Hamad in his handwriting on Mr. Rashad Abdul-Muttalib's copy of Al-Maymani's edition, text: 'Qarqad is a mountain you leave while heading to [Taif] after passing the village of Al-Zaymah on your left. The people of that area call it Qardad, corruptly'.
7. Thus in Sifat Jazirat al-Arab 121 and Mu'jam al-Buldan (7: 35, 56) and in Yaqut (in entry Ma'dan al-Baram) and Al-Zamakhshari in Kitab al-Jibal 155 'Al-Baram' with the weight of 'Qufl'. Yaqut recited for Al-Quhayf: I have settled in Ma'dan al-Barakah a settlement ... So with difficulty, yes difficulty, from Adakh I moved. And recited in Al-Lisan for Abu Sakhr al-Hudhali: Even if what I carried, its load was borne by ... The peaks of Radwa or the summits of Baram. Al-Zamakhshari said: 'Wadakh is a market with buildings and a group of people belonging to Banu 'Amilah, and it is Ma'dan al-Baram'. And 'Wadakh' which Al-Zamakhshari mentioned is a dialect for 'Adakh'. See Al-Zamakhshari 5 and Mu'jam al-Buldan (Adakh). It will come before the discussion on ([Taif]) with the wording 'Al-Baram'.
8. Al-Bakri mentioned it in entry (Sin Muhmalah), 765 and casually with Sin Muhmalah also in 788. Al-Zamakhshari mentioned it 88 in Sin Muhmalah. As for Yaqut, he mentioned it in Shin Mu'jamah once, and another in Sin Muhmalah, and appeared to think it a misspelling. In Al-Hamdani 172 'Shawan' with dotted letter [Shin].

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: one of which is Shawan. All these mountains belong to Ghamid, Khath'am, Salul, Sawa'ah bin Amir, and Anzah. All these mountains grow Acacia (*Qaraz*); they are leading mountains with gaps between them. The poet said describing a rain: A Ghori [cloud] went to Najd and its Tihami part moaned / And its dark clouds rushed between its first drops (1) / And the edges of Al-Sarat watered. In the Sarat mountains there are grapes, sugarcane, Acacia (*Qaraz*), and *Ishil*. In all these mountains there is vegetation and trees of *Gharb* and *Basham*, except Yasum and Qarqad, for they grow nothing but *Nab'* and *Shawhat*. Hardly anyone ascends them except after effort. Monkeys take shelter in them, and their spoiling of the sugarcane (2) owners is frequent. In these mountains are fresh water seepages and springs, except Qarqad and Yasum, for there is nothing in them except what gathers in the rock pools (*Qilat*) (3) from rainwater, such that it cannot be reached nor its place known. The poet said about Yasum and Qarqad: I heard, while my companions were urging their mounts ... With us between a corner of Yasum and Qarqad (4) / So I said to my companions: Stop - may you have no father! - ... The chests of the mounts, for indeed this is the voice of Ma'bad (5). The road from Bustan Ibn Amir to [Mecca] is via (Qufl). Qufl: The pass that
foot_note:
1. *Istanna*: Went quickly. *Al-Rayyiq*: The first of a thing. *Rayyiq al-matar*: The first of its downpour. *Al-Hantam*: Clouds. In the original: 'Antamah', corrected in Yaqut (Al-Sarat).
2. Yaqut: 'Sugarcane which grows in the mountains of Al-Sarat'.
3. *Al-Qilat*: Plural of *Qalt* with Fatha; it is like a hollow in the mountain where water stagnates.
4. Al-Bakri 788: 'Their mounts trot ... from Yasum and Badbad'.
5. Yaqut in entry (Qarqad): 'Indeed it is the voice of Ma'bad'.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and their Inhabitants, Villages, Trees, and Water
publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: brings you out to (Qarn al-Manazil [As Sayl al Kabir, Saudi Arabia]) facing [Taif]. It pushes (1) you from your left while you aim for [Mecca]. Leading mountains, they are high red mountains, most of their vegetation is Acacia (*Qaraz*). Among the mountains of [Mecca] is (Abu Qubays (2)). And among them are (Al-Safa) and (The Red Mountain (3)), and a high black mountain called (Al-Hayla) from which stones are cut for building and millstones. (Al-Marwah) is a mountain that tends towards redness (4). (Thabir (5)) is a towering mountain, faced by (Hira) which is a towering mountain higher than Thabir. At its top is a slippery, high peak (6). They mentioned that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ascended its summit with a group of Companions, and it shook. So the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to it: "Be still, Hira, for upon you is none but a Prophet, or a Siddiq (Truthful), or a Shahid (Martyr) (7)." [There is no vegetation on them nor in all the mountains of [Mecca] except a little of
foot_note:
1. The origin of *Lahz* is pushing and hitting. *Al-Lahiz*: The mountain pushes the road and hits it, likewise the hill hits the road.
2. Yaqut cited in (1: 94) many sayings regarding the reason for its naming.
3. Yaqut mentioned it in entry (Al-Ahmar).
4. This is a rare expression, and 'ma' in it is extra, meaning 'to redness it is'. Similar to what appeared in Mashariq al-Anwar by Qadi Iyad Vol 1 p 324 regarding his saying in the Hadith of Tamim al-Dari about the Dajjal: 'No, rather from the direction of the East he is (*ma huwa*)'. He said: 'Ma here is a connective and not negative, meaning from the direction of the East he is'.
5. In [Mecca] there are other Thabirs: Thabir of the Zanj where they used to play, Thabir al-Khadra', Thabir al-Nas' which is the mountain of Muzdalifah, and Thabir al-Ahdab. From Yaqut.
6. *Al-Zaluj*: Smooth, one who ascends it slips.
7. See Mu'jam al-Buldan (Hira). In Mu'jam al-Bakri 432: 'Be firm Hira, for upon you is only a Prophet or a Siddiq or a Shahid'. What is in Sahih al-Bukhari in the Virtues of the Companions of the Prophet, peace be upon him, from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, is that the Prophet, peace be upon him, ascended Uhud and Abu Bakr, Uthman and Umar were with him, so it shook with them. He said: 'Be firm Uhud, for upon you is a Prophet, a Siddiq, and two Martyrs'. It came in Fath al-Bari (7: 33) commenting on it: 'It is the well-known mountain in [Medina]. In a narration by Muslim and Abu Ya'la from another path via Sa'id: Hira. The first is more correct. Were it not for the unity of the exit [narrator], I would have allowed the multiplicity of the story. Then it appeared to me that the difference is from Sa'id; for I found it in the Musnad of Al-Harith bin Abi Usama from Ruh bin Ubadah from Sa'id, saying in it: Uhud or Hira, with doubt. Ahmad extracted it from the Hadith of Buraydah with the wording: Hira, and its chain is authentic, so the probability of the story's multiplicity is strengthened. It preceded in the ends of the Waqf from the Hadith of Uthman similarly, and in it Hira. Muslim extracted from the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah -

publisher: Mustafa Al-Babi Al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text: *Dahya'* which exists in the towering mountain (1)], and there is no water in any of them. Then the mountains of (Arafat) connect to the mountains of [Taif]. In them are many waters, seepages, and *Fuqar* channels (2), among them (3) (Al-Mashash), which comes out at Arafat and connects to [Mecca]. [From Qu'ayqa'an to [Mecca] (4)] is twelve miles on the road of Al-Harf (5) to Yemen. (Qu'ayqa'an) [in Mecca]: a village with waters, crops, palms, and fruits; it is the Yamaniyah (6). Between [Mecca] and [Taif] is a village called (Rasib) belonging to Khath'am, and (Al-Jawnah (7)): a village for the Ansar, and Al-Ma'dan (Ma'dan al-Baram (8)), which has many palms and crops. The waters are well waters,
foot_note:
1. - what supports the multiplicity of the story, mentioning he was on Hira and those mentioned here were with him, and added others with them. And Allah knows best.'
1. The completion is from Yaqut in entry (Hira). Al-Maymani did not establish it. See for *Al-Dahya'* what preceded on p. 396.
2. *Fuqar*: Plural of *Faqir*, previously explained by Arram. Al-Maymani read it 'Yafir' corruptly, and interpreted it saying 'increases', thinking it from 'Wafara', an illusion.
3. In the original: 'Kada'im' corruption. *Al-Kaza'im*: Plural of *Kazimah* with Kasra, which is a channel inside the earth in which water flows. Al-Asma'i said: They are aligned wells dug and spaced out, then a channel is pierced between every two wells leading the water from the first to the next underground, so their waters gather flowing, then emerge at their end flowing on the surface of the earth. *Al-Fuqar* was previously explained on p. 413. The text is corrupted in Yaqut in entry (Al-Mashash).
4. Completion from Yaqut in (Qu'ayqa'an). Al-Maymani did not establish it.
5. Thus. In Yaqut 'Al-Hawf' with Waw.
6. Thus in Yaqut's transfer: Meaning the Yemeni fruits.
7. Thus Yaqut established it in its entry and said: 'A village between Mecca and Taif'. It was written in the original 'Al-Jawiyah' with pointed letters, and Al-Maymani read it 'Al-Jawbah'. Sheikh Hamad said: 'It is, as I see, Al-Hawiyah with unpointed Ha, broken Waw, doubled Ya underneath, and feminine Ta: A village among the most famous villages of Taif still known by this name even if not mentioned in ancient dictionaries like many places in the land of the Arabs'. But Yaqut's restriction of it, and its being between Mecca and Taif not in Taif itself, contradicts what the Sheikh imagined.
8. Previously discussed in footnotes of p. 416.

text: they irrigate their crops with *Zaraniq* (1). ([Taif] (2)) possesses farms, palms, bananas, grapes, and other fruits. It has flowing waters and valleys pouring from it to Tabalah. Most of the people of [Taif] are Thaqif and Himyar, and a group from Quraysh, and Ghawth from Yemen (3). It is one of the mother (4) villages. (Matar (5)): a village among its villages with many crops and bananas. (Tabalah) is larger than it,
foot_note:
1. Plural of *Zarnuq* with Damma or Fatha. The *Zarnuqan*: Two walls built at the head of the well on its two sides, upon which the *Na'amah* is placed, which is a piece of wood laid across them, then the pulley is suspended in it, the rope of the bucket runs in it to draw water. One says *zarnaqa zarnaqah*, meaning watered with the *Zarnuq*... The verb 'tazarnaqa' is also used. In the Hadith of Ali: 'I will not abandon Hajj even if I *tazarnaqtu*', meaning even if I serve the well pulleys and draw water to gather the expense of Hajj.
2. Yaqut listed many explanations for its naming. Al-Bakri said: It was named after the wall they built around it and encompassed (*atafu*) it with for fortification. Its name was Wajj. Umayyah bin Abi al-Salt said: We built a fortified Taif ... Striking down heroes defending our sons. Its summer resort status is known from ancient times. Al-Numayri said about Zaynab bint Yusuf, sister of Al-Hajjaj, describing her luxury: She winters in Mecca in luxury ... And her summer resort is in Taif.
3. 'And Ghawth from Yemen' did not appear in what Yaqut quoted from Arram (6: 11). In Yemen there are Aghwath: one is Ghawth bin Anmar bin Arash bin Amr bin Lihyan bin Amr bin Malik bin Zayd bin Kahlan. Another is Ghawth bin Tayy bin Udad bin Zayd bin Yashjub bin Arib bin Zayd bin Kahlan. Likewise Al-Ghawth bin Nabt bin Malik bin Zayd bin Kahlan. And Al-Ghawth bin Udad bin Zayd bin Kahlan. Nihayat al-Arab (2: 296, 310) and Al-Ma'arif 53 and Al-Sihah, Al-Taj, and Al-Lisan (Ghawth).
4. In the original 'Ummayat', but *Umm* is pluralized as *Umat* and *Ummahat*; the first plural prevails for non-rational things. But the known usage in such expression is *Ummahat*, as the author himself used before when discussing (Waddan) p. 405.
5. Al-Bakri: 'Abu Hanifa said: Abu Ishaq al-Bakri informed me that in Matar there are always ripe date palms, palms being harvested, palms turning red/yellow, and palms being pollinated'. He and Yaqut vocalized it with Damma on the Mim. See Al-Hamdani 121, 241.

text: between them is two nights. In [Taif] there is a pulpit, and in Tabalah there is a pulpit. Its people are Salul, Uqayl, Ghamid, Amir bin Rabi'ah, and Qays Kubbah (1). At the border of Tabalah is a village called (Ranyah (2) [Ranyah, Saudi Arabia]), and a village called (Bishah (3) [Bishah, Saudi Arabia]), and (Tathlith [Tathlith, Saudi Arabia]), and (Yabambam (4)), and (Al-Aqiq, Aqiq Tamrah (5)). All of them belong to Uqayl. Their waters are *Buthur* (6). *Al-Bathr* resembles *Al-Ahsa'* (shallow wells), flowing under the pebbles at a depth of a cubit, two cubits, or less than a cubit; sometimes beasts expose it with their hooves.
foot_note:
1. Qays Kubbah: A tribe from Bajilah, as in Al-Lisan (2: 192). In Mu'jam Ma Ista'jam 61: 'And Qays Kubbah - and Kubbah was a horse of his - son of Al-Ghawth bin Anmar, among Banu Ja'far bin Kilab'.
2. Yaqut and Al-Bakri created an entry for it, with Fatha on Ra, then Yaqut returned and created an entry for it in (Zabyah) with Fatha on the dotted Zay, and said: 'Thus it is recorded in the book of Arram'.
3. Al-Ahwas deleted the Ha from it saying: She settles in Khakh or the slope of Suwayqah ... And my journey is in Bish or Tihamah or Najd. It is different from the Lion-infested place (*Ma'sadah*) to which lions are attributed; that is Bishah of Al-Samawah about which Muzarrid says: High peaks in it as if their father ... In Bishah is a lion thick of forearms. This is what Al-Bakri mentioned, but Yaqut made the *Ma'sadah* Bishah of Tihamah not Bishah of Al-Samawah. Sheikh Muhammad bin Bulayhid did the same in Sahih al-Akhbar (1: 176) and said: 'In this era, two tribes reside in it, Banu Salul and Banu Mu'awiyah. There are two cities in it, the city of Banu Salul called Al-Rawshan, and the city of Banu Mu'awiyah called Nimran'.
4. Hamid bin Thawr al-Hilali mentioned this place and the two places before it in his saying: If she wished she sang to me in the winding valleys of Bishah ... Or the palms of Tathlith or of Yabambam.
5. Every watercourse cut by a torrent in the earth, forming a riverbed and widening it is called: (*Aqiq*). In the land of the Arabs there are many Aqiqs, among them this Aqiq, and Aqiq al-Yamamah, and Aqiq al-Madinah which is famous - named so because it cut (*'aqqa*) from its Harrah meaning cut off - and Al-Aqiq which is in the belly of Wadi Dhu al-Hulayfah, and Aqiq al-Qanan, in which the torrents of the peaks of Najd and its mountains flow. In Iraq there is Aqiq al-Basra.
6. See what preceded regarding *Al-Buthur* on p. 410 line 7.

text:
The Border of Hijaz
Arram said: The border of Hijaz is from (Ma'dan al-Naqrah (1)) to [Medina]; half of [Medina] is Hijazi and half is Tihami (2). Among the Hijazi villages is (Batn Nakhl). Opposite Batn Nakhl is a mountain called (Al-Aswad); half of it is Najdi and half is Hijazi. It is a towering mountain, and grows nothing but herbage (3), like *Silliyan* (4), *Ghadur*, and *Gharaz* (5). Then (Al-Taraf (6)) for one aiming for [Medina], flanked by three mountains: One is (Zulum), a black towering mountain growing nothing, and (Hazm Bani Awwal); both belong to Ghatafan (7). In Awwal there are wells, among them (Bir Alyah) - the name of the sheep's tail - and (Bir Harmah),
foot_note:
1. Yaqut: Al-Naqrah, with Fatha on Nun and Sukun on Qaf. Al-Azhari narrated it with Fatha on Nun and Kasra on Qaf. In Al-Lisan: 'Ibn al-A'rabi: Every land descending into a depression is *Naqrah*, and from it Naqrah on the road to Mecca was named, which is called Ma'dan al-Naqrah'. Yaqut said: This is what is relied upon for the name of this spot.
2. Ibn Abi Shaybah mentioned that [Medina] is Hijazi. As for [Mecca] it is Tihami, and [Taif] is Hijazi.
3. In the original: 'ghayra kala', corrected from Yaqut. Omission of the Lam of definition occurs often in the handwriting of the original scribe.
4. With Kasra on Sad, doubling of the broken Lam, and lightening of Ya. About it is the proverb: 'He uprooted it like the wild ass uproots the Silliyanah'. See Al-Lisan (Sall).
5. This word was not established by Yaqut from Arram in entry (Al-Aswad). The Ghayn in the original was drawn resembling Kha, so I read it in the first edition 'Al-Kharaz', then I found Al-Maymani had corrected it: 'Al-Gharaf'. Sheikh Hamad said: The correct word is Al-Gharaz with Ghayn not Kha, and it is so in the original. Al-Gharaz: A type of plant resembling *Thumam*, described in language dictionaries and known in the land of the Arabs.
6. Al-Taraf, with movement [voweling], as Yaqut recorded in its entry.
7. He did not mention the third mountain. The investigator Sheikh Sulayman al-Sani' pointed this out. He said: 'The third is Al-La'ba', Yaqut mentioned it in his dictionary from Ibn Musa'. See entry (Awwal) in Mu'jam al-Buldan. Sheikh Hamad said commenting on what I wrote: 'I say: Al-Samhudi pointed this out in Wafa' al-Wafa Vol 2 p 347 before Professor Al-Sani''.

text: and (Bir Umayr), and (Bir al-Sidrah (1)); there is no useful water in these (2). And (Al-Sadd) is rainwater; the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered it to be dammed. And among them is (Al-Qarqarah (3)), which is rainwater. These waters do not cease due to the abundance that gathers in them. From Al-Sadd there is a canal to (Quba). Surrounding [Medina] among the mountains is ('Ayr): two red mountains on your right when you are in the belly of Al-Aqiq (4) intending for [Mecca] (5). On your left is (Shawran (6)), which is a mountain overlooking Al-Sadd, large and high. To the south (Qibli side) of [Medina] is a mountain called (Al-Sari), which is one (7), not upon this...
foot_note:
1. In Al-Bakri 1326: 'Hafirat al-Sidrah'.
2. The phrase is clear in the original despite neglecting the final Hamza in 'ha'ula'' and 'ma''. Al-Maymani made it: 'wa laysa biha ma yuntafa'u [bihi]'.
3. In the original: 'wa huwa al-qarqar', corrected to 'Al-Qarqarah', which is what is called 'Qarqarat al-Kudr'.
4. This is Aqiq of [Medina].
5. Yaqut said: 'Some people of Hijaz mentioned to me that in [Medina] there are two mountains called: 'Ayr al-Warid (The Arriving 'Ayr) and the other 'Ayr al-Sadir (The Departing 'Ayr), and they are close to each other. This agrees with Arram's statement'.
6. Shawran with Fatha on Shin. Among the news mentioned about it is that (Al-Baghum), the companion of Rayhan al-Khudari, vowed to walk from Shawran until she entered all the gates of the Mosque, led by a rein of gold. A poet said: Would that I were among them on the morning of their arrival ... From the pass of Shawran, possessing two earrings, reined. Walking on hard ground, her fingertips bleeding ... And around her are the Qibtriyyah (Egyptian linen) dark-lipped women. The people of Naqi' al-Dar spent the night, filled by ... A pungent musk, while a gazelle walks among them.
7. Meaning not two mountains as 'Ayr is two mountains. Yaqut said: 'Al-Sari in the language of Egyptian merchants is the ship's mast. Al-Jawhari said: Al-Sari is the sailor'. Yaqut's statement that it is the language of Egyptian merchants ..., for this meaning was known to the Arabs of old. In the Hadith of Ibn al-Zubayr: 'He ordered a *sawar* (mast/pole) so it was set up around the Kaaba'. I see its derivation is from *sara yasri*, if it rose high. They say: The she-camel *sarat* her neck, if she raised it from the heaviness of the load. He recited: * And the white camels between lowering and raising high (*sari*) *

text: vegetation nor water, except for Shawran, for in it are many rainwater sources called Al-Bajarat (1), 'Karam' (2), 'Ayn', and 'Am'awhum ma yakun al-Sanan' (3). In all of them are black fish, the size of an arm or less than that, the best fish there is. A mountain opposite this Shawran is called (Maytan (4)); in it is well water called (Daffah (5)), and it has no vegetation at all; it belongs to Sulaym and Muzaynah. Opposite it is a mountain called (Sann (6)) and large, lofty mountains called (Al-Hula' (7)), singular Hula'ah (8)
foot_note:
1. Yaqut: 'With movement (vowels), and it is said: Al-Bujayrat, using the diminutive form.' In Al-Bakri 906, it is (Al-Bahrat) with an un-dotted Ha, and likewise in Wafa' al-Wafa' 2:331.
2. See its entry in Al-Bakri.
3. This phrase appeared as such in the original, and it is clear that the context is a listing of names of springs. Sheikh Hamad commented on it with a strange comment, may Allah preserve him: 'The Professor has an excuse for being ignorant of some locations he has not traversed and for which he found no texts to clarify their locations completely, but what is his excuse for being ignorant of linguistic words—he being the linguist who undertook the publication of some linguistic dictionaries—and we mean by words what we find circulated in printed language dictionaries? On p. 55—of the first edition—is this text: (wa-am'awhum ma yakun al-sanan), and the Professor commented saying: Thus this phrase appeared in the original. Had he referred to language books, he would have found that Al-Am'a' are places where water collects and remains for a long time' (Thus. I do not know which printed dictionaries this strange text cited by the Sheikh appeared in). Then the Sheikh said: 'Therefore, the sentence is (wa Am'a' wa huwa ma' yakun al-sanin)!? [And Am'a', which is water that lasts for years/is stagnant!?]. And thus this sentence appeared in what Al-Samhudi quoted in Wafa' al-Wafa' vol 2 p 331 from 'Arram.' I leave the comment on this comment to the fair reader.
4. Yaqut vocalized it with a Fatha on the Meem, and Al-Bakri with a Kasra. Ma'n bin Aws Al-Muzani says about it: As if there never was, O Umm Haqqah, before this ... at Maytan, a summer resort for us and spring camps.
5. In the original: 'Da'ah', its correction is from Al-Bakri's dictionary in its entry and in (Zulm) as well.
6. This matches what is in Yaqut where he says in its entry: 'And Al-Sann is also: a mountain in Medina near Uhud.' He also said in (Al-Hula'ah): 'Arram said: Opposite Maytan, among the mountains of Medina, is a mountain called Al-Sann.' But in Al-Bakri 819, 906 it is 'Shiyy', with a Kasra on the Sheen.
7. With Fatha on the Ha and Kasra, as mentioned by Yaqut. In Al-Bakri 389, 906 it is: 'Al-Jalah' with a Kasra on the first letter, on the wording of the plural of Jalhah). Al-Fayruzabadi said: 'And with Kasra, singular Al-Hula', for mountains near Maytan from which millstones are hewn.' It is vocalized in Al-Lisan with Fatha.
8. Al-Zamakhshari recited in Kitab al-Jibal 50 for Ibn al-Riqa': -

Then to (Al-Rahdiyah (1)), a village belonging to the Ansar and Banu Sulaym, from Najd (2); it has wells with many crops and palm trees. Opposite it is a village or land called (Al-Hijr (3)), and it has water from springs and wells belonging to Banu Sulaym. Opposite it is a small mountain, not lofty, called (Qunnat Al-Hijr (4)). There is a high valley called (Dhu Rawlan (5)) belonging to Banu Sulaym, containing many villages that grow palm trees, among them (Qulha (6)), which is a large village, and (Taqtad (7)), also a village. Between them is a mountain called (Adimah). At the top of this valley are meadows called (Al-Fallaj), gathering people during the days of spring. In it are many holding places (ponds) (8) which suffice them for their summer and spring if

1. Thus Yaqut vocalized it. As for Al-Bakri, he made it 'Al-Ruhaydah' in the form of the diminutive of (Al-Rahdah). See 645, 874, 908.

The explanation of (Al-Masak) appeared previously on p. 397 line 7.

text: it rains. There are no wells or springs in it. Among them is a pond called (Al-Mukhtabi (1)) because it is between thorny trees ('idah), lote trees (sidr), salam trees, and willows (khilaf) (2). It can only be approached from its two ends, not its sides, because it has an edge that no one can manage (3). Among them is a rock hollow (qalt) (4) called (Dhat Al-Qarnayn) because it is between two small mountains, and water is only extracted from it by drawing with buckets if it drops (5) a little. Among them is a pond called (Ghadir Al-Sidrah), having some of the purest water, with no trees around it. Then you proceed ascending towards Mecca [Makkah, Saudi Arabia], and you turn to a valley called ('Urayfitan Ma'n (6)), which has no water or pasture. Opposite it are mountains called (Ubla (7)), and opposite it is a peak called (Al-Sudah (8)) belonging to Banu Khafaf from Banu Sulaym, and their water is
foot_note:
1. In Al-Bakri 907, 1187: 'Al-Mujanni', and the correct one is what is here as understood from the reasoning, which matches what is in Yaqut in (Al-Fallaj).
2. Al-Khilaf: Willow trees, also called 'Al-Sawjar', and its varieties are many, all of them soft and weak. Al-Aswad said: As if you are a branch of willow seen to have ... a beauty, while weakness comes to it from above.
3. Sheikh Hamad mentioned in a comment that in Wafa' al-Wafa' 2:369 quoting 'Arram: 'because it has two edges that cannot be managed from their direction.'
4. The explanation of (Al-Qalt) appeared previously on p. 417.
5. I made it 'inkhafada' (masculine) in my first edition relying on Yaqut in (Al-Qarnayn): As for Al-Maymani, he made it 'inkhafadat' (feminine) correcting what was in the original which was 'inkhafazat' (with Zaa). The virtuous Sheikh said correcting and commenting: 'I say: The correct reading—in my view—is what appeared in the original (meaning the correctness of the original word structure, which is 'inkhafadat' not 'inkhafazat'), for the water as understood from 'Arram's speech is between two small mountains, so the one coming to it needs to descend a little to reach it and extract it with the bucket.'
6. In the original: 'Ma'ran' un-dotted, its correction is from Yaqut in ('Urayfitan, Ubla). Al-Maymani read it 'Urayfitan Ma'rifah', which is an oversight in reading and investigation.
7. This Ubla is shortened (Alif Maqsura), and it is different from (Ubla) like 'Kursi', which is a known mountain near Aja' and Salma. Al-Maymani read it by mistake: 'a mountain called Ubla'.
8. Thus it was vocalized in Mu'jam al-Buldan. In Al-Bakri 99, 815 it is (Al-Shawrah) with a Fatha on the Sheen.

text:
(Al-Sa'biyyah (1)), which are wells drawn from; it is fresh water and vast land. There used to be a spring there called (Al-Naziyah (2)) shared between Banu Khafaf and the Ansar, but they fought (3) and blocked it. It is a spring with abundant fresh water, and many people were killed for that reason. The Sultan of the land requested it multiple times for a large price (4), but they refused that. In Ubla, there are waters including (Bi'r Ma'unah) [Bi'r Ma'unah, Saudi Arabia], (Dhu Sa'idah (5)), (Jamajim) or (Hamahim) - doubt (6) -, and (Al-Wasba'). These belong to Banu Sulaym, and they are connected peaks, one to another. The poet said about them:
Oh, would that I knew, has there changed after us ... Arum, then Aram, then Shabah, and Al-Hadr (7)?
And have my camels left the blackness of Ubla's mountains ... [And has Al-Hijr departed after me from its small peak?] (8)
foot_note:
1. In the original: 'Al-Sa'idah', corrected from Yaqut in its entry and the entry of (Al-Surah), and likewise Al-Qamus (Sa'b) where it says: 'And Al-Sa'biyyah: a water for Banu Khafaf.'
2. Al-Bakri said: 'On the pronunciation of Fa'ilah from Naza Yanzu.' And Naza Yanzu: to jump and leap.
3. The virtuous Sheikh said in a comment: 'In Wafa' al-Wafa' vol 2 p 380: fa-tadarrau (they harmed each other), and in Yaqut: fa-tadaddu (they opposed each other), with Dal is a misspelling. The Professor chose the word tadarabu (they fought/struck each other) like Professor Al-Maymani, but I see fa-tadarrau as more correct.' I say: The writing of the original allows both my reading and his reading, for the word was drawn as 'tadarabu' but placed above the Ra in the original is what looks like a Shadda and above the Ba a Damma. There is no doubt that Tadrarub, meaning conflict and disagreement, is closer to the strength of the phrase than 'Mudarrah' meaning exchanging harm.
4. The word 'bi-althaman' (for the price) is fixed in the original. I do not know how Professor Al-Maymani missed it, so he established it as an addition to the original relying on Yaqut's Dictionary entry (Al-Sa'biyyah) and Mu'jam Ma Asta'jam p. 60, and mentioned with that that 'The original is blank' despite its clear presence in the original.
5. Sa'idah, originally, is one of the names of the lion.
6. This word was drawn in the original with poor drawing such that the reader might think it a slip of the pen. Therefore, I did not establish it in the first edition, but I found after finding Professor Al-Maymani's edition this time that he was able to read it and said commenting on it: 'Thus with doubt from Al-Sakuni in Yaqut's Dictionary and Mu'jam Ma Asta'jam 60, 22244'.
7. Yaqut in the entry of (Ubla): 'fa-al-Hadr'.
8. The completion is from Yaqut. In the original: 'And has Layla left'.
