publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text:
[Opposite Ubla is a mountain called (Dhu al-Mawqa'ah (1)) to its east, and it is the mountain of (2)] the Mine of Banu Sulaym [Mahd adh Dhahab, Saudi Arabia], in which mountain goats (3) are numerous. In the lower part of its east is a well called [(it)] (Al-Shaqiqah (4)). Opposite it, on its right from the direction of the Qibla, is a mountain called (Bartham) and a mountain called (Ta'ar). They are two high mountains that grow nothing, in which leopards (5) are numerous. At the base of Bartham is a water called (Dhanaban Al-'Iys (6)), and there is no water near Ta'ar. And [Al-Kharb]: a mountain between it and the Qibla, which grows nothing stable (7). The poet said:
I have worn out, but Ta'ar does not wear out, nor do I see ... Yaramram except stable, renewing itself (8)
Nor Al-Kharb the near one, as if its peaks ... are Bactrian camels upon which imply coverings, sleeping (9)
foot_note:
1. It is in Al-Bakri (Al-Mawqa'ah) in its entry and on p. 199.
2. And this completion is also from Yaqut in the entry of (Al-Mawqa'ah).
3. In Yaqut, quoting 'Arram, it is replaced by (Al-Lazaward / Lapis Lazuli), and the correct face is what is in the original and Al-Bakri 99. Lapis Lazuli: A stone among the precious stones. Dawud said in his Tadhkirah: A famous mineral generated independently in the mountains of Armenia and Persia, and found in the faces of minerals, and the purest of it is that which is in gold. The best of it is the clear, heavy, transparent one whose blueness leans towards some greenness and redness.
4. Ibn Muqbil says about it: So the basins of Dhu Baqar, then the rugged ground of Shaqiqah ... a wasteland, and other than wastelands may enrich. Yaqut made it with the wording (Al-Shafiqah) in its entry.
5. In the original: 'Al-Namir Kathir' (The leopard is numerous), and its correction is from Yaqut in (Bartham) and (Ta'ar): Al-Nimran is plural of Nimr (leopard), and likewise Dhi'b and Dhu'ban (wolf).
6. And likewise in Yaqut. In Al-Bakri 616, 814: 'Dhanabah Al-'Iys'.
7. It appeared distorted in the first edition: 'nabitan' (growing) due to a typographical error.
8. The word (thabitan) is not clear in the original. Its establishment is from Yaqut's Dictionary in (Yaramram).
9. Qilal: plural of Qullah, which is the summit of the mountain. Al-Bukhati: plural of Bukhti like Kursi, which are camels with long necks. Al-Ajillah: plural of Jilal, and Al-Jilal, with Kasra: is the cover of everything, and it is also the plural of Jull (cloth) of the beast which it wears to be protected. Hujjad: plural of Hajid and Hajidah (sleeping). In the original: 'jahd', corrected from Yaqut (Yaramram, Al-Kharb). Al-Bakri 99 narrated the two verses with a different narration.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text: He passes the spring of (Al-Naziyah (1)) and comes to waters (2) called (Al-Hudabiyyah (3)), which are three wells with no farms, palm trees, or trees upon them. It is a large low ground (Qa') (4) that is three farsakhs in length, whatever Allah wills (5). It belongs to Banu Khafaf between two black volcanic tracts (Harratayn), and their water is not fresh; the vegetation there is mostly salty plants (Hamd). Then he ends up at (Al-Sawarqiyyah (6)) [Al Suwayriqiyah, Saudi Arabia] at three miles from it. It is a thriving village with many people, containing a pulpit, a congregational mosque (7), and a large market to which merchants come from the regions; it belongs to Banu Sulaym especially. Everyone [of (8)] Banu Sulaym has a share in it. In its water is some saltiness. They seek fresh water (9) from wells in a valley called (Sawariq), and a valley called (Al-Abtan (10)), light fresh water. They have farms and many palm trees and fruits, including bananas, figs, pomegranates, grapes, quinces, and peaches, which are called Firsik (11). They have
foot_note:
1. The word Al-Naziyah did not appear in the original except for (Al-Na).
2. In the original (miyah), and its correction is in Al-Bakri, and in Yaqut (Al-Hudabiyyah): 'ma'ah' (a water source).
3. In the original: 'Al-'Adamah', corrected from Yaqut and Al-Bakri 99.
4. Al-Qa': A vast, easy, low, level land with no ruggedness or elevation, from which mountains and hills part. In Yaqut: 'biqa' kabirah', plural of Buq'ah, and likewise in Al-Bakri 99: 'in vast biqa''.
5. In the original: 'ma sala minhu' (what flowed from it), corrected from Yaqut and Al-Bakri.
6. With Damma on the Seen and Fatha. It is also said: 'Al-Suwayriqiyah', in the diminutive form.
7. Yaqut quoting 'Arram: 'Jami'' (Congregational).
8. The completion is from Yaqut.
9. Isti'dhab: drawing fresh water. In the Hadith, it is said that 'water used to be sought fresh (yusta'dhab) for him from the houses of Al-Suqya', meaning fresh water was brought to him from there.
10. Thus vocalized with Damma on the Ta in Yaqut (Al-Sawarqiyyah) and Al-Bakri (Ubla).
11. It is said to be a fruit like the peach in size. Al-Jawhari said: 'A type of peach that does not split from its stone.' It is said: It is the fig. Shamir said: 'I heard an eloquent Himyari woman whom I asked about her land, and she said: The palm trees are few, but our living is am-qamh (wheat), am-firsik, am-hamat (figs). Tub - meaning good -. So I said to her: What is Al-Firsik? She said: It is am-tin (figs) to you.' The word Firsik appeared in Persian meaning peach: A Peach. Steingass 618.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text:
horses, camels, and many sheep. They are Bedouins (1) except for those born there, for they are residents (2) in it, while the others are Bedouins around it. They provision the road of Hejaz [Hejaz] and Najd [Najd] on the two pilgrim roads. The border is (Dariyya) [Dariyah, Saudi Arabia], and their border ends there at seven stages. They have villages around them, including a village called (Al-Qayya) whose water is salty bitter (Ma'j) (3) like the water of Al-Sawarqiyyah; between them is three farsakhs. It has many inhabitants, palm trees, farms, and trees. The poet said:
How good is the milk mixed with water (Madhq) with the water of Al-Qayya (4) ... when I have eaten Barni dates (5) after it.
And a village called (Al-Malha' (6)), which is in the belly of a valley called (Qawran) that flows from the Harrah (7). It has many waters and wells, fresh and good, and palm trees and trees. Around it are the hills of (Dhu Majr (8)). The poet said about them:
At Dhu Majr, I was watered by the downpour of the morning clouds (9) ...
foot_note:
1. In the original 'thalatha'??? without dots, corrected from Yaqut. However, the phrase before it is distorted in his text, as it is 'wa sha' wa kubara'uhum badiah' (and sheep, and their elders are Bedouins).
2. Thus in the original. I had read it in the first edition 'thabitun' (firm/staying). The virtuous Sheikh Hamad said: The meaning of 'tanun' is staying/resident, from 'tana'a', and the Hamza was eased. Professor Sheikh Abd al-Rahman al-Mu'allimi al-Yamani pointed this out.
3. Al-Ma'j: The salty. Yaqut: 'Ujaj' (bitter/salty). Al-Maymani made it 'Ujaj' and did not note the original, even though what is in the original is correct.
4. Al-Madhq: Milk mixed with water. Al-Bakri: 'bi-ma' Qayya'.
5. Al-Bakri: 'qablahu' (before it) instead of 'ba'dahu' (after it). Al-Barni: A type of yellow round date.
6. Al-Bakri said: 100 'It was named after Al-Malhah, a branch of Haydan.'
7. It is Harrat Sulaym which is called Harrat al-Nar.
8. Yaqut vocalized it with Fatha on Meem and Sukun on Jim, and considered its movement in poetry later due to necessity. As for Al-Bakri, he vocalized it with movement (Fatha on both).
9. Yaqut: 'ghawadi'.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text:
And Dhu Majr is a large pond in the belly of this valley of Qawran. At its top is a water called (Laqaf (1)), water of many wells, fresh, with no farms or palm trees upon them due to the roughness and ruggedness of its location. Above that is a water called (Shass (2)), water of fresh wells. Above that is a well called (Dhat Al-Ghar), fresh with abundant water that irrigates their valley. The poet—who is 'Adhirah bin Qitab (3) Al-Sulami—said:
You terrified me on the day of Dhat Al-Ghar with a fright ... with bad news, before which was my graying.
You announced the death of the youth of Qays bin 'Aylan in the morning ... and its knight, you announce his death to a beloved (4).
Opposite it is a mountain called (Aqrah (5)), lofty, elevated, barren, growing nothing, with many leopards and mountain goats. Then you proceed from Al-Malha' and end up at a mountain called (Maghar (6)), inside which
foot_note:
1. In Al-Bakri 100 it is replaced by: 'Layth'. In the first edition, it appeared as 'Al-Qafa', inadvertently.
2. The original meaning of Al-Shass is hard ground that is like a single stone, plural Shisas and Shusus.
3. Yaqut and likewise Ibn Taghri Birdi: 'Ghazirah bin Qitab'. In Al-Bakri 100: 'Ibn Qitab said'. In Al-Tabari: ''Azizah'. Ghazirah bin Qitab Al-Sulami was the leader of Sulaym in their revolt against the Sultan during the caliphate of Al-Wathiq. He used to charge reciting Rajaz poetry saying: There must be crowding even if the door is narrow ... I am I, Ghazirah bin Qitab / For death is better for the youth than shame. He continued fighting until he was killed and crucified. That was in the year 230. Al-Nujum Al-Zahirah (2: 257-258) and Al-Tabari (11: 12-14).
4. Yaqut did not narrate it. In Al-Bakri: ''Uqwah' instead of 'Ghadwah'. Li-Habib means you announce his death to one who loves him. In Al-Bakri: 'Li-Habibi', interpreted as the estimation: He is indeed my beloved.
5. Yaqut did not create an entry for it, but Al-Bakri did and discussed it in 'Ubla'.
6. In Al-Bakri 100: 'Ma'an'.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text: are seeping waters (Ahsa'), among them a seeping water called (Al-Haddar (1)) which gushes with abundant water, and it is in a salt marsh (Sabakh) (2). Opposite it are two black protected tracts (Hamiyatayn) (3); inside one of them is a salty water (4) called (Al-Rafdah (5)). Its valley is named ('Urayfitan), and upon it are small palms and thickets (Ajam) where the passerby seeks shade; singular Ajam (6), and they are like palaces. Around it are Humud (salty plants) (7), and it belongs to Banu Sulaym. It is on the road of (Zubaida) [Darb Zubaydah, Saudi Arabia/Iraq]; Banu Sulaym call it (Manfa Zubaida (8)). Opposite it is a mountain called (Shawahit), with many leopards and many mountain goats. In it are springs (Awshal) growing Ghadur and Thagham. Opposite it is a valley called (Barak) with abundant vegetation of Salam, 'Urfut, and varieties of trees. In it is a water called (Al-Buwayrah (9)), which is fresh and good, from (Bi'r Shakk) and it is
foot_note:
1. The word is not clear in the original, appearing as 'Al-Madar' without dots. Its establishment is from Yaqut in (Maghar, Al-Haddar) and Al-Bakri 101 and the entry (Al-Haddar). Al-Haddar is also: from the regions of Al-Yamamah where Musaylimah the Liar was born. Yaqut said: 'It is possible that it is from Al-Hadr, which is the invalidation of blood, or from the braying (hadr) of the camel, when it rumbles in its throat.'
2. Al-Sabakh, with movement: The place becomes salty (yasbakh) so salt grows in it and feet sink in.
3. The explanation of 'Al-Hamiyah' appeared previously on p. 413.
4. Yaqut quoting 'Arram: 'Malihah'. Al-Malihah and Al-Milhah mean the same.
5. Thus Al-Bakri vocalized it with letters in its entry, and Yaqut did not vocalize it. It is vocalized in Al-Qamus with a Fatha on the Ra.
6. Al-Ujum, with two Dammas: The fortress. And with a Damma and two Dammas: Every square flat-roofed house. They recited for that the saying of Imru' al-Qays: And Tayma, He left not a palm trunk within it ... Nor a fortress (Utum) except built with stones.
7. In the original: 'Hamus' with un-dotted letters, correct is with Dad (dotted). Al-Humud: plural of Hamd, as in Al-Qamus. Al-Hamd, with Fatha: What is salty and bitter of plants.
8. Thus in the original. In Yaqut's Dictionary: 'Manqa Zubaida'. See entry (Maghar). Al-Maymani read it 'Maghfa', inadvertently.
9. Yaqut said: 'Diminutive of the well (Al-Bi'r) from which water is drawn.'

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text:
the saddening Ghayqah (1), but it does not run dry. There is (Bartham), a lofty mountain with many leopards and mountain goats, with little vegetation except what is of Thagham, Ghadur, and the like. Opposite it is a valley called (Baydan (2)) containing many water wells and many trees; wheat, barley, and alfalfa (Qatt) (3) are grown on these wells. Opposite it is a valley called (Al-Sahn). The poet said about it:
We brought from the south of Al-Sahn short-haired horses ... noble, lean, offspring of offspring (4)
So we came with them on the two days of Hunayn to ... the Prophet of Allah, sharply, not in jest.
In it is a water called (Al-Haba'ah), which consists of mouths of many wells with pierced bottoms; some empty into others of the water place, fresh and good (5). Wheat, barley, and the like are grown on it. And another water, a single well, called (Al-Rassas (6)), abundant in water, not planted (7) upon due to the narrowness of its location.
foot_note:
1. Thus appeared 'Bi'r Shakk wa hiya Al-Ghayqah Al-Shajwah'. It is worth mentioning that 'Shajwah' is a valley in Tihamah, and 'Ghayqah' is between Mecca and Medina.
2. Al-Bakri created an entry for it, and Yaqut did not.
3. The word is un-dotted in the original. Al-Qatt: Alfalfa (Fisfisah) and fresh pasture (Ratbah), which is what is called 'Barsim' in the tongue of the Egyptians. See Dawud's Tadhkirah.
4. Al-Jurd: plural of Ajrad and Jar'da', which is the short-haired horse. Al-Nasl: verbal noun of Nasala Yansilu, meaning to speed. Yaqut: 'Sarrah naslan li-nasl'. Al-Bakri: 'Sayyaraha naslan li-nasl'. Shuzaban: plural of Shazib, which is lean. In the original: 'sarban???' un-dotted. Sheikh Hamad has the credit for this correction which I missed in the first edition.
5. Yaqut: 'some into others, the good fresh water'.
6. Thus Al-Bakri vocalized it in its entry, and mentioned it also in 'Shawahit', and Yaqut did not create an entry for it. In the original: 'Arsas', and the scribe of the copy often omits the definite article Lam.
7. Al-Bakri in (Shawahit): 'la yuzdara'' (is not cultivated).

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text: At the bottom of this Baydan is a place called (Al-'Iys) containing water called (Dhanaban Al-'Iys (1)). Al-'Iys: Where the trees of Salam and Dal become numerous, it is called 'Iys and Khays (2). Opposite it is a mountain called (Al-Harras (3)), black with no good vegetation. At its base is a pond (Adah) (4) called Al-Hawaq (5) which holds much water from the sky; it all belongs to Banu Sulaym. Opposite that is a village called (Sufaynah (6)) [Sufaynah, Saudi Arabia], containing farms and many palm trees (7), all of that on wells. It has a mountain called (Al-Sitar). It is on the road of (Zubaida (8)); the pilgrims turn to it if they are thirsty. Opposite it are other waters called (Al-Nujayr), [and opposite it is a water source called (Al-Nujarah), a single well (9)], and both contain saltiness but not severe (10).
foot_note:
1. See previous footnotes on p. 430.
2. Al-Khays and Al-Khaysah: Many entangled trees. In the original: 'Habs' distorted.
3. Al-Bakri mentioned it in its entry, and in (Al-Sitar), and in (Shawahit). In one of the copies of his original: 'Al-Hurad'. Yaqut did not create an entry for it, nor did he mention it, tracing Wüstenfeld's indices.
4. Al-Adah: The pond, and water stagnant from a torrent or otherwise, plural Adawat and Ida.
5. In the original: 'Al-Haqa'iq' omitting dots. Its correction is from Al-Bakri in its entry and in (Shawahit), Al-Zamakhshari 49, and Al-Qamus (Hawq). It is like Kitab and Ghurab, as mentioned by Al-Bakri and the author of Al-Qamus.
6. Yaqut created an entry for it, and Al-Bakri did not, nor did he mention it. It is like the sack ('aybah) in which a man's belongings and tools are kept.
7. In Al-Maymani's copy: 'wa Nakhil' (and palms) distorted from what is in the original.
8. Yaqut: 'Al-Zubaydiyah'.
9. The completion is from Yaqut in the entry (Al-Nujayr), and from what follows. In Al-Bakri 721 and 336, 'Al-Thujjar' and 'Al-Thujjir'. Yaqut did not create entries for them under Tha, but made them 'Al-Nujarah' and 'Al-Nujayr' with Nun, in their entry and in 'Najl'.
10. Thus in the original and it has a validity. In Yaqut: 'wa laysat bi-l-shadidah' (feminine).

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text: Below them in a level desert are two tall pillars (1) which no one can ascend unless he is a bird. One of them is called ('Amud Al-Ban), and (Al-Ban (2)) is a place, and the other is ('Amud Al-Safh). It is to the right of the road ascending from Kufa [Kufa, Iraq] (3) at a mile from (Ufay'iyah). (Afa'iyah (4)) [Afa'iyah, Saudi Arabia] is a large, lofty plateau, but the name of the village is (Dhu Al-Nakhl (5)), and it is one of the stages of the road. It has salt. Fresh water is sought for it from this Al-Nujarah and Al-Nujayr (6), and from a water called (Dhu Mahbalah (7)). To its left is a water source called (Al-Subhiyyah (8)), which is a single well with no farms upon it,
foot_note:
1. The phrase appeared identically in Yaqut (Al-Ban, and 'Amud) from 'Arram. In Al-Bakri 721, without declaring the transfer: 'And below them are two tall plateaus'. This is an explanation of the two pillars, meaning they are two high plateaus, each resembling the pillar of a house. The application of (Al-'Amud) to a plateau is not known in language dictionaries.
2. Al-Ban with the wording of that known plant in Yaqut. In Al-Bakri in its entry and in (Al-Sitar): 'Alban' as if plural of Laban (milk).
3. In Al-Bakri 722: 'From Kufa to Mecca'.
4. Al-Bakri vocalized it with Damma on the Hamza, then said: 'Thus narrated from 'Umarah bin 'Aqil. Others narrate it Afa'iyah with Fatha on the Hamza. Both examples exist in Names and Attributes, and the Damma on the Hamza in Ufa'iyah is more established, and it is what Abu Hatim and others chose.'
5. Thus in the original. Al-Bakri 314 recited for Jamil: And the likes of Al-Muqattam intervened before her ... and Dhu Al-Nakhl from the valley of Qatah and Ta'niq. In Yaqut: 'Dhu Al-Najl' with Jim, and likewise in Al-Zamakhshari 67.
6. The explanation of Isti'dhab (seeking fresh water) appeared on p. 431. Al-Nujarah and Al-Nujayr were discussed on the previous page.
7. Yaqut created an entry for it, and mentioned it also in (Najl), and Al-Bakri did not mention it. In the original: 'Majilah'. Al-Maymani thought it 'Dhu Nukhaylah'.
8. Al-Bakri created an entry for it, and Yaqut did not create an entry for it nor mention it in his dictionary, tracing Wüstenfeld's index.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text:
and water is sought from it for the people of Afa'iyah. Opposite it is a large plateau called (Khatmah (1)), and a lava field (Labah) (2) - which is a rough (3) black volcanic tract that grows nothing - called (Manihah (4)); it belongs to Jasr and Banu Sulaym. And a village called (Marran) [Marran, Saudi Arabia], a large thriving village, with many springs, wells, palm trees, and farms. It is on the Basra road [from Iraq] belonging to Banu Hilal and Jasr (5), and to Banu Ma'iz (6). It has a fortress and a pulpit, and many people. The poet says about it (7):
After the tall, lofty ones of the family of Ma'iz, does a wayfarer hope for hospitality at Marran (8)?
foot_note:
1. What is in Al-Bakri 722: 'Hadmah' with Damma and two Dammas.
2. Al-Labah: The Harrah (volcanic tract), plural La'b and Lub.
3. Al-Harshafah: Rough ground.
4. In the original: 'Sahah' un-dotted, establishing it from Al-Bakri 722.
5. This word fell from the first edition.
6. Yaqut in the entry of (Marran): 'And a part to Banu Ma'iz'.
7. The virtuous Sheikh said: The Professor did not extract the two verses appearing in (Marran), and they are from a poem among the finest elegies consisting of 18 verses cited by Al-Hajari in full, mentioning its author and the one eulogized. He said: Abu Kulayb Hamr bin Al-Ashhab, from Banu Amir bin Rabi'ah, recited to me for Al-Tamimi, regarding Ma'iz bin Malik Al-Baka'i, and it is complete here: News of the death of the noble Ibn Malik came to me ... so I spent the night while the night in Iraq was long / I spent the night consoling myself lest the enemies rejoice ... while in the soul there is burning thirst from grief over him. Abu Tammam cited some of it in Al-Hamasah. I say: See also Sharh Al-Marzuqi p. 1062 - 1063.
8. In the original: 'Hayy bi-Marran Al-Qura', corrected from Yaqut.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text:
We passed by Marran at night and did not turn ... to the people of thickets and palm trees therein (1).
Behind it is a village called (Quba (2)) [Quba, Saudi Arabia], large and populated, belonging to Jasr, Muharib, and Amir ibn Rabi'ah of Hawazin. It has many farms on wells, and not many palm trees. Opposite it is a mountain called (Hakran), and a mountain called [it] ('Ann). The poet said:
Peaks of Hakran, the dark ones (3) ...
It has little vegetation. At its base is a water called (Al-Sanw (4)). This 'Ann has waters and springs inside it. The poet said about it:
So they said: We are Hilalis, we came from our land ... for a need for which we crossed the night as a cloak (5)
And they said: We went out filling Qafa and its south ... and 'Ann, so the heart was about to crack (6).
(Al-Qafa (7)): A mountain belonging to Banu Hilal opposite this 'Ann. Opposite it is another mountain
foot_note:
1. Yaqut: 'Ajam biha' (thickets in it).
2. This Quba is the one on the road from Mecca to Basra. It is different from Quba of Medina.
3. A'yan, with Nun in the original copy, matching what Yaqut narrated from 'Arram in (Hakran). In Al-Bakri 722: 'A'yar' plural of 'Ayr. Al-Khudari with Damma on Kha: The black, used to describe clouds, eagles, camels, and hair.
4. Neither Al-Bakri nor Yaqut created an entry for it. The first mentioned it in (Al-Sitar) and the other in (Hakran).
5. Meaning we entered inside it as the wearer enters his cloak (Mydra'). Al-Mydra' like Minbar: A jubbah split in the front.
6. This narration matches Yaqut's narration in ('Ann). Al-Bakri's narration: 'fi Al-Faqa'.
7. Al-Bakri created an entry for it and said: 'On the wording of the Qafa (back of neck) of a human.' Yaqut did not create an entry.

book_title: Names of the Mountains of Tihamah and Their Inhabitants, and What Villages Are In Them, and What Trees Grow On Them, and What Waters Are In Them
publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt [Egypt]
text: called (Bass (1)). At its base is a water called (Baq'a' (2)) belonging to Banu Hilal, a well with much water, having no crops. Opposite it is another called (Al-Khudud (3)). 'Ukaz is a call's distance from it (4). ('Ukaz) [Souq Okaz, Saudi Arabia] is a level desert with no mountain or landmark (5) except what used to be of the idols that were in the Jahiliyyah. In it are blood [stains] from the blood of sacrificial animals like great millstones (6). Opposite it is a spring called (Khulays) belonging to the Amriyyin (7). This Khulays is a man
foot_note:

and it is in a land called (Rukbah (1)) [Rukbah, Saudi Arabia]. The poet said:
I say to a caravan one day [I met them] ... driving lean, bare-footed, limping camels (2)
Who are you? For we have desired your coming ... and that you inform us of the state of Rukbah entirely (3).

The book of the names of the mountains of Mecca and Medina and what connects to them is completed, by the praise of Allah, His aid, and His good success. And may Allah bless our Master Muhammad whenever the rememberers remember him, and the heedless overlook mentioning him.
foot_note:
1. Rukbah with the wording of the knee (Rukbah) in the leg. It is between Mecca and Taif. In Al-Lisan: 'Between Ghamrah and Dhat 'Irq.' It is said: Rukbah is the highest of all lands. It is said: It is the one about which Noah's son said: 'I will take refuge on a mountain to protect me from the water.' In Fada'il Makkah by Al-Hamdani, Umar bin Al-Khattab said: To commit seventy sins in Rukbah is more beloved to me than to commit one sin in Mecca. Malik narrated in Al-Muwatta' that Umar bin Al-Khattab said: 'A night in Rukbah is more beloved to me than ten nights in Al-Sham.' Malik said: 'He means for the length of lives and survival, and for the severity of the plague in Al-Sham.'
2. I did not find a reference to verify these two verses despite long searching. The word 'laqituhum' (I met them) is not in the original, and with something like it, the speech becomes coherent. Tazjiyah: Driving. Anda': plural of Nidw, with Kasra, which is the emaciated camel. Hawafi: Those whose feet have become bare/worn from walking. Zali': One who has Zala', which is a limp similar to lameness.
3. The first hemistich of the verse appeared in the original in this form: 'Min ism yaya qad hawyna majikum'. I established it likewise in the first edition. After seeing Al-Maymani's edition this time, I found he read it this close reading. So credit belongs to him. And praise be to Allah for what He has bestowed.
